  • IIS site name of Configuration Manager, it was aligned to use the name “ ABB Control Systems Operations”, see 800xA branding wiki.

Title: Container | Configuration changes for Configuration manager
Description:
It is mentioned that manual updates shall be executed in Installation and Configuration Container Guide - Overview (azure.com) :

  • Update the C:\Program Files\ABB Control Systems\Operations\Thin Client\services\configuration.manager\appsettings.json. (Replace the parameters <OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>, <DOMAIN_NAME>, <DEPLOY_USER>, and <800XA_HOSTNAME> with appropriate values.)

      "ConfigurationManager": {
    "Receivers": [
      {
        "ReceiverId": "WorkplaceBackEndService",
        "Url": "https://<OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>/"
      },
      {
        "ReceiverId": "PG2BackEndService",
        "Url": "https://<OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>/pg2/"
      },
      {
        "ReceiverId": "TrendBackEndService",
        "Url": "https://<OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>/trend/"
      },
      {
        "ReceiverId": "AlarmsBackEndService",
        "Url": "https://<OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>/alarms/"
      },
      {
        "ReceiverId": "ObjectExplorerBackEndService",
        "Url": "https://<OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>/objectexplorer/"
      }
    ]
  },
  "DeployAdapter": {
    "TimeoutSeconds": 300,
    "MaximumFileSize": 10737418240,
    "WorkingDirectoryPath": "%AppDataPath%",
    "DeployUsers": ["<DOMAIN_NAME>\\<DEPLOY_USER>"]
  },
  "Auth": {
    "Authority": "https://<AUTHORITY_URL>:442/auth-server",
    "ClientId": "<800XA_HOSTNAME>ABBThinClientCM",
    "Scope": "ABBThinClient/deployapi"
  },  
However, this manual updates shall be removed via changes for Configuration manager. The Configuration manager shall automatically update the parameters <OC_CLUSTER_HOSTNAME>, <DOMAIN_NAME>, <DEPLOY_USER>, and <800XA_HOSTNAME> from System installer.

Title: OPC UA Client Lib Configuration - PG2- Read settings from ObjectDirectory
Description:
Description:
Today there is a configuration section in each UA Client Lib - users appsettings where OPC UA Server(s) to be connected to can be configured.
The intention is to move this information into ObjectDirectory and let the Deploy Tool populate this information.
This is done so that redundancy configurations and also support for (transparent) connections to multiple servers is to be implemented.

Doing this also removes the need for at installation time distribute the endpoint url(s) which will help System Installer in upcoming features.

Technical details:
In order for the OPC UA Client library to get then information stored in ObjectDirectory two options were available;
  1. Create a dependency between UA client lib and ObjectDirectory and do an implementation to be reused for everybody.
  2. Dont create a dependency but instead define an interface for this in UA lib which all users have to implement. This will typically be by reading object directory and providing the data. So the implementation in all NGT backend services will pretty much be identical.
We decided that option 2 is better for multiple reasons;
  • Get away from the annoying dependency
  • Testability, this can now easily be mocked
  • Makes the lib useable in situations where object directory is not available.
Expected work from each team:
Pretty much copy paste what PG2 will do, we will create a class that reads object directory and implements the interface required by UA lib and push it in with dependency injection. We estimate this to be 2 hours coding and then some testing. The other teams can copy this.

Title: OPC UA Client Lib Configuration - Alarm & Event - Read settings from ObjectDirectory
Description:
Description:
Today there is a configuration section in each UA Client Lib - users appsettings where OPC UA Server(s) to be connected to can be configured.
The intention is to move this information into ObjectDirectory and let the Deploy Tool populate this information.
This is done so that redundancy configurations and also support for (transparent) connections to multiple servers is to be implemented.

Doing this also removes the need for at installation time distribute the endpoint url(s) which will help System Installer in upcoming features.

Technical details:
In order for the OPC UA Client library to get then information stored in ObjectDirectory two options were available;
  1. Create a dependency between UA client lib and ObjectDirectory and do an implementation to be reused for everybody.
  2. Dont create a dependency but instead define an interface for this in UA lib which all users have to implement. This will typically be by reading object directory and providing the data. So the implementation in all NGT backend services will pretty much be identical.
We decided that option 2 is better for multiple reasons;
  • Get away from the annoying dependency
  • Testability, this can now easily be mocked
  • Makes the lib useable in situations where object directory is not available.
Expected work from each team:
Pretty much copy paste what PG2 will do, we will create a class that reads object directory and implements the interface required by UA lib and push it in with dependency injection. We estimate this to be 2 hours coding and then some testing. The other teams can copy this.





Scope: 
- Alarm and Event service implement interfaces, method calls to read configured OPC UA Server URLs from Object Directory database.  
- Alarm and Event service implement exception handling and logs in case of failure to read valid OPC UA Server URLs.   


Given: OPC UA Server service providers are configured in System 800xA and new Object Directory database is deployed using available Deploy Tool.
When: Alarm and Event service call the method to read OPC UA Server URL's from Object Directory database. 
Then: Method call returns the configured and deployed OPC UA Server URLs.

Given: Deployed new Object Directory database does not have data for OPC UA Server URL's.
When: Alarm and Event service call the method to read OPC UA Server URL's from Object Directory database.
Then:  Alarm and Event service handle the exception and create a log.

Title: OPC UA Client Lib Configuration - Trend - Read settings from ObjectDirectory
Description:
Benefit\Background: There is a configuration section in each UA Client Lib - users appsettings where OPC UA Server(s) to be connected to can be configured.
The intention is to move this information into ObjectDirectory2 and let the Deploy Tool populate this information. This is done so that redundancy configurations and also support for (transparent) connections to multiple servers is to be implemented.

Doing this eliminates the need for at installation time distribute the endpoint url(s) which will help System Installer in upcoming features.

Scope: Team Sierra is expected to implement the solution in PG2 service, creating a class that reads ObjectDirectory2 and implements the interface required by OPC UA lib and push it in with dependency injection. This code from PG2 is expected to be reused into Trend services thus implementing the solution.

Notes:
In order for the OPC UA Client library to get then information stored in ObjectDirectory two options were available;
  1. Create a dependency between UA client lib and ObjectDirectory2 and do an implementation to be reused for everybody.
  2. Do not create a dependency but instead define an interface for this in UA lib which all users have to implement. This will typically be by reading object directory and providing the data. So the implementation in all NGT backend services will pretty much be identical.
We decided that option 2 is better for multiple reasons;
  • Get away from the annoying dependency
  • Testability, this can now easily be mocked
  • Makes the lib useable in situations where object directory is not available.
Out of Scope: Maintaining the backward compatibility with appsettings based configuration, it shall be ignored. 

Related link if dependency to other features: Refer Links tab.

Title: Identify and evaluate the activities for trend performance improvements
Description:
Benefit\Background:

In Trend application, having non-functional requirement defined helps to define what system will not do and defines the boundaries, thus preventing scope creep. This also help R&D team to focus on the core functionalities that are critical.

Resource allocation, by understanding what is not required, resources can be allocated more efficiently thus avoiding waste on features or capabilities that are not needed.

User-centered design, contributes to design approach by eliminating unnecessary features that may clutter the interface or compliance to the user experience.

In general, a detailed study is required to figure out list of possible activity to improve trend performance.

Scope: It is proposed to further study the following item that can possible contributing in improving the trend performance:
  • Isolating texts
  • Isolating animations
  • Optimizing canvas
  • Initial loading
  • Life-cycle time, frame rate to be monitored.
  • Improve the rendering (mainly focusing to optimize badly rendered pixels)
  • Benchmarking of resources such as hardware footprints, orechestor provided info, and network bandwidth.
  • Possible improvement requirements in OPC UA Client library.
  • Possible log messages (diag.) info to be printed in the log.
Out of Scope: Any actual performance improvement implementation.

Related link if dependency to other features: Refer Links tab.

Title: Workplace | CommonHMI Default Configuration Definition
Description:
Background: Currently Windows Manager is working both as the main site of the Operations Client web app and as a microservice for navigation/licensing/context menu. To reach the target solution, the CommonHMI should functionally replace completely the Windows Manager Frontend part, becoming the main site of the Operations Client web application. This newly replaced CommonHMI FE is provided with quite lot of configurations that are specific to default behavior of CommonHMI and not tuned for NGT HMI.


Scope: The default configuration of workplace shall be adjusted as per NGT HMI needs and shall be shipped into the product. This includes: SystemConfiguration, Navigation Menu, CURL calls through Team AJ scripts.


Out of Scope:  Data validation and sanitization of configuration of CommonHMI 5.x BE.


Related link if dependency to other features: Refer Links tab.

Title: CommonHMI 5.x | Workplace Adoption [No split view and tab control]
Description:
Background: CommonHMI is being used as common framework as workplace in NGT HMI, and base workplace functionalities are inherited while specific functionalities of HMI needs being adapted in custom nature. CommonHMI 5.x alpha version is planned to be released which bring improvements and new functionalities.

Scope: The following activities shall be covered:
  • Workplace shall be upgraded to CommonHMI 5.x. version.
  • Upgrade to latest APUX Lib version utilized by CommonHMI FE for our FE components.
  • Custom Chart Definition and integration with WindowsManager and Trends.
  • Installation scripts update with CRDs in charts for configuring CommonHMI 5.x
  • Support to Team AJ for handling Offline Scenarios and to other teams in adapting CommonHMI 5.x (individual services).
  • Default configuration of CommonHMI 5.x (SystemConfiguration, Navigation Menu, CURL calls through Team AJ scripts.
  • Effort for integrating up to 5 releases of CommonHMI 5.x builds.

Title: Adapt ConfigurationServiceApi and Configuration Manager to support node deployment [Stretch]
Description:
Benefit\Background: It is proposed to have multi node support for deployment. The entire deployment flow for multiple node scenario is described Deploy Flow 800xA 7_0_xP0 - Overview (azure.com)


Scope: The necessary changes in ConfigurationServiceApi and ConfigurationManager to support new multi node deployment shall be carried out. The following activities shall be completed:


Modifications in ConfigurationManager:

  • Evaluate whether to call a new Health Check endpoint to monitor whether the cluster is up and running (No service-level granularity, just cluster status), or alternatively utilize the Kubernetes Api for the same purposes. Another alternate could be "Unable to complete the "Open" phase, then this could assumed be Health Check failure, hen terminating the deploy".
  • Evaluate authentication requirements for the above options, and choose the one with the lowest effort without compromising security. Authentication for the aforementioned endpoint shall be validated.
  • Depending upon the solution provided by DeployTool (Linked feature), add a KVP table within the Configuration Manager (appsettings) to associate target cluster IDs to their actual addresses, or plain address list to associate target cluster IDs.
  • Ensure to call any newly added Healthcheck endpoint before initiating the actual deploy to a node.
  • Since we assume the package remains the same, all targets shall receive the same one.
  • Ensure integrity and other security checks on the received compressed archive, then parallel threads shall be started to perform the deployment to each target.
  • Ensure that Commit/Rollback/Failure operations are atomical for each target node [as the user should be aware of all single results, this might require modifications (to be confirmed) on the Deploy Tool, in order to print detailed feedback]
  • Ensure time-out management to single target cluster is in place and set accordingly, this ensures that the user is not waiting for longer period. After time-out, rollback shall be executed. In general, a failure on a node is nothing but failure of all nodes. In other words break and exit.
Note: CommonEventLog based solution shall be discarded hereafter. 
Out of Scope: Items that are not explicitly mentioned in the scope. Audit trail for deployment.

Related link if dependency to other features: Refer Links tab. Also the following:

Predecessors:
Feature 609735: DeployTool Add Deploy targets to MANIFEST file - Boards (abb.com)
Feature 609728: AfwConfigure - Add NGT Node Types - Boards (abb.com)
Feature 604944: SR-6613: SI for NGT - Possible to add new NGT OS node - Boards (abb.com)

Title: Execute a configuration audit PI 24.3
SR-6624 Configurable level of diagnostic and telemetry data
Description: It should be possible to configure the log level of services running in containers on NGT OS. Configuration will be done using a UI provided by NGT OS platform and it will override the default log level configured in appsettings.json via an environmental variable. The mechanism for this exists in NGT Platform.

Title: Trend NGT History Engine Support
Description:
Benefit\Background: NGT History implemented OPC UA HDA Server functionality to expose historized data to any OPC UA HDA client as part their requirement. Addrespace model adheres to NGT model. They would like to demonstrate their OPC UA HDA capability by utilizing NGT HMI's Trend application.

Scope: Extend the support on-demand to NGT History team in order to demonstrate the OPC UA HDA Server capabilities using NGT HMI's trend application. 

Out of Scope: Support on OPC UA Client Lib.

Note:

NGT History team had multiple session with NGT HMI (Trend Client team in ABB Italy), Below is the summary of investigation till now in PI 24.2

 

  • Steps attempted to integrate client with HA Server as below

 

  1. Modified the Trendapi appsettigns.json file where URL is pointing to NGT History OPCUA HA Server
  2. Restarted the IIS for Thin client service & Refresh the operation client browser
  3. certificate handshake was not established between opcua client and opcua server.
  4. Manually copied the ABB History OPCUA Server certificate from History server to GDS trusted folder
  5. GDS pushed the ABB History OPCUA Server certificate from its trusted folder to trendapi trusted folder automatically.
  6. Manually copied the 3 certificates/crl files from thin client to history server trusted folder (ABB operation client trends, 800xA BuiltIn-Issuing /root certification authority to HA Server)

 

Result :Connection could not be established between HMI Trend client and History Server, due to certificate authorization, Trend client certificate is issued by 800xA/GDS and NGT HA Server certificate is self-signed.

 

  • Other way tried to investigate in Debugging environment

 

  1. NGT History HA Server code is cloned to the HMI Trend Client application node.
  2. Updated the Trendapi appsettigns.json file where URL is pointing to NGT History OPCUA HA Server.
  3. Refresh the operation trend client browser/restart IIS.
  4. Below log info is received in History HA Server diag folder

2024-04-15 15:50:56.781 +05:30 [INF] ChannelId 3: ProcessCloseSecureChannelRequest

2024-04-15 15:50:56.781 +05:30 [ERR] TCPSERVERCHANNEL ForceChannelFault Socket=FFFFFFFF, ChannelId=3, TokenId=1, Reason=BadConnectionClosed 'Remote side closed connection.'

 

Result: No Connection between HMI Client and NGT History OPC UA HA Server code (connection successful calls not received)

 

  • Next Steps suggested by HMI client dev team, to install Trend client in non-800xA env.

 

  1. Able to login to thin client on non-800xA node by resolving Identity server issue, updated the appsettings file with required url then resolved the issue.
  2. Now when thin client attempting to connect HA Server, error is seen ,update of AuthServerDB for new non-800xa client is done, still unable to connect, investigation continued
  3. Manually entered the Non 800xA Trend client ID into AuthServerDB where ever applicable inside the AuthServerDB, still no success.
  4. AuthServerDB file shared to HMI Trend client Team for investiagtion.

 

After this effort till now it seems like 800xA 6.2 Thin client package is only for 800xA OPCUA Server as per requirement, Does not work with NGT History OPC UA Server, this needs a more investigation and can be exploratory where HMI trend client team support is required.

Title: OPC UA Diagnostics | Alarm list / Event list
Description:
Alarm list / Event list backend service exposes diagnostic information via OPC UA Server. This data will be subscribed and visualized by 800xA UA Connect/SMT.

For 7.0xP0, only backend service status (shall be according to OPC UA DeviceHelth) will be exposed.
  • "Normal" if service runs correctly
  • "Failure" if service is disconnected from OPC UA Server.
Note:  if a service failure, the service itself cannot generate any alarm. An external subscriber such as 800xA UA Connect would have the capability to diagnose the connection failure.

Scope:

OPC UA Server library is integrated with #197844 , update the library to latest available release version.

Prerequisite: Operations Client is deployed and configured to connect with OPC UA Server. 
(consider redundancy support which will be implemented in future)
Given: Alarm and Event Service is running     
When: Alarm and Event Service is able to connect with OPC UA Server.   
Then: Alarm and Event list service expose the status as "Normal".

Given: Alarm and Event Service is running     
When: Alarm and Event Service is not able to connect with OPC UA Server.   
Then: Alarm and Event list service expose the status as "Failure".

Given: Alarm and Event Service is running     
When: Alarm and Event Service is failed itself.   
Then: No diagnostic information is available.

Title: OPC UA Redundancy | Affinity
Description:
STRECH FEATURE - FURTHER BREAKDOWN NEEDED

Requirement:

•Have affinity in mind when implementing 1-3 basic redundancy.
•If we have time to implement affinity lets implement this:
1.Deploy an affinity option, ”Prioritzed or random” where
we either take the ”master” – to be defined in info model
or random to random which provider to connect to.
2.Affinity is only for UA Lib to UA server.

Title: OPC UA Library Redundancy | Dispatch to multiple DataSourceGroups (UA-server groups)
Description:
Requirements:

•Subscribe/Read/Write/MethodCalls should be dispatched to the correct
OPC UA server based on the DataSource it is associated with
•Event (and alarm) subscriptions should be dispatched to all OPC UA servers.
(Same NodeId might exist in several OPC UA servers, so i think we should go for all).
Also add posibility to in requests specify ”DataSource” so it can be sent to a specific
OPC UA server
•Refresh needs to go to all OPC UA servers
•History reads – should by default go to the server the item
is associated with based on DataSource [TODO: what
if a specific history server is desired? Add config
possiblity for it? Do we need a ”HistoryDataSource”?]
Maybe allow specifying DataSource on interfaces?
•

Not included:

•No failovers, no other redundancy

More info in powerpoint attached to the parent.

Some additional info:

This will force us to:

•Implement Data Source lookup, performance is important here!
•Handle special cases for Alarm, we need to add support for;
  Subscribe to all events in DataSourceGroup X
  Subscribe to all events in all DataSourceGroups
  Refresh to all DataSourceGroups
•Handle different history server source

Things to consider:

•This needs to work for all functionality in UA Lib
•We need to handle partial cases, X of N items in
request are in a disconnected server etc.
•X of N items are for datasource 1 and rest for
datasource 2

Title: OPC UA Library Redundancy | Connect to multiple OPC UA Servers
Description:
Requirements:

• At startup, connect to all deployed DataSources
• All connection statuses needs to be available to lib Consumer (events)
• All Connection statuses needs to be available through some diagnostics [Requires a way to expose status through OPC UA for example] (Is not supported in 800xA UA server)
• User sessions should be created towards all OPC UA servers when ”created to one”

Not included:

• No dispatching, all calls goes to one UA Server
• No failovers, no other redundancy
• No user mappings for 3rd party UA Servers.
(Should be handled through internal aggregating
OPC UA server in that case).


More info available on powerpoint attached to parent.

Some additional info:

This will force us to:

•Read Object Directory Data
•Handle multiple OPC UA servers
•Handle Status and Connection events
•Structure code to be ready for redundancy impl.
•Adapt public interfaces

Things to consider:

•Dev environments, would be good with a
backdoor to override deployed data
•ObjectDirectory is now a pre-req for
OPC UA Lib, i guess we should
have interfaces so that it can be mocked.
•To test arbitrary UA servers we need to
manually manipulate the deployed DB.
(or by a tool, or by modified deploy).

Title: SR-5530 Trend trim curve
Description:
The trim curve will start accumulating data and show as a trend line as soon the trend with the selected signal is opened. The trim curve shall store the data locally within the trend. The trend will discard the stored values when it is closed. On all other user actions within the trend the trim curve will continue storing and using the already saved points. The trim curve shall have a sizable value limit per trend line - default min. is 800xA (1200 points) however the expected limit is at least 5000 points. The runtime data of trim curves are acquired using OPC UA DA interface.
The configuration of trim curve shall be fetched from deploy tool. The "Log type" is used to identify trim if its value is TRIM. The deploy tool shall be extended to support TRIM log type.

Title: Alarms and events | Multi-view support
Description:
It should be possible to host one or more alarm list and event list in multi view. It shall support content visualization techniques like preserve and replace. The definition of multiple shall be up to 4 number for any unique HMI application (aspect types).

It should be possible to show each alarm list and event list view as per their deployed configuration.

It should be possible that each alarm list and event list view subscribe to 800xA OPC UA Server as per their configured filter.

In each alarm list view, it should be possible to perform view specific operations like sorting, pause, alarm acknowledge, shelving, context menu navigations. 

In each event list view, it should be possible to perform view specific operations like pause, priority filters, time scope, context menu navigations.

Title: Restructure Object Directory Contracts
Description:
Today the dll Operations.ObjectDirectory.Contract.Types is located in TFS together with the Deploy Tool code.
These contracts are used both from the Deploy Tool but also from the Object Directory Repo in Git.

It would make more sense to move this contract dll to the ObjectDirectory repo, since for example when S+ creates a deploy tool they should also use the same contracts dll, and the common denominator is ObjectDirectory.

Title: SR-5918 Behavior Driven Development
Description:
Share point link for project: Reduction in Defect Leakage through Behaviour Driven Development


Problem Statement: In certain modules,  it has been found that bugs are found late in the development cycle and in some case in SIT and STT phases.  This could cause potential delays in the internal releases and add to rework effort.​

 

Business Case: In order to achieve “shift-left”, bugs related to functionality and performance should be caught early in the development cycle. With BDD (Behavioral Driven Development) on identified set of feature(s), we would like to achieve shift left when it comes to finding bugs and reduce late finding of issues.​

 

Scope: Operations Client Features-  targeted for implementing Behavior Driven Development ​

1 Pause and Unpause -  Event list RU1  2 Multirow selection - Alarms 7.0 (OC 3.0)​

 

Out of scope: BDD approach is focused more on backend components of the features and would not cover the scenarios and tests driven from the Front end User interface of Operations Client.​

 

Process: BDD using Gerkhin syntax for scenarios and developers / testers using SpecFlow .NET and incorporate it in CI/CD pipeline – Coding and assertion

 

Risks and Limitations​

Behaviour Driven Methodology is new approach for the developers which they have not been exposed to before.  Might require some ramp up time for them to get conversant fully with the methodology.​

 

SMART Objective Statement​

Reduce bug leakage of i.e. the no of bugs found in PIT, PTT, SIT and STT Phases and also to reduce late finding of regression issues resulting in Smoke test failures in Release builds. Reduction of bug leakage to less than10 % for the following features: Pause and Unpause - Event list RU1 & Multirow selection - Alarms 7.0 (OC 3.0)​

 

Timeline​

2024-04-11

2024-06-12​

Title: [Stretch] BDD for Multi Row Selection & Pause / Unpause
Description:
Alarm list should have ability to select multiple rows of alarms in an alarm list. It should be possible to show and perform common menu options on selected row of alarms. 

 

 

Prerequisite

OC Alarm list subscribed to 800xA OPC UA Server and receiving new alarm for example 1 alarm/sec.   

OC Alarm list has multiple standing alarms, some acknowledged and some unacknowledged and some RTN. Alarms with ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

  

Given

OC Alarm list has multiple standing alarms, some acknowledged and some unacknowledged and some RTN.

Alarms with ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

 

When

User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

Then

All the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  


Given

Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

When

User click on "Acknowledge alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarms which are UNACK get Acknowledged. Selected alarm rows should get un-selected.      

 

Given

Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]         

When

User click on "Acknowledge visible alarms" button in tool bar. 

Then

Selected alarm rows should get un-selected. All visible UNACK alarms get acknowledged.          

 

Given

Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

When

Some selected alarm rows with ALARM_STATE = RTN-UNACK are acknowledged by other client, and got removed from alarm list view.

Some selected alarm rows with ALARM_STATE =  ACT-ACK become RTN, and got removed from alarm list view. 

Then
Remaining selected alarm rows which are not removed from alarm list view should still stay selected. 


Given

Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

When

User click on "Pause" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get paused.          

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state.

Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

When

User click on "Play (Un-pause)" button in tool bar. No alarm acknowledge is performed. 

Then

Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get un-paused.          

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

When

User click on "Acknowledge alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

ACK column of selected alarms which are with UNACK state get blue dot and check mark.      

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]

When

User click on "Acknowledge visible alarms" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarm rows should stay selected. ACK column of all visible UNACK alarms get blue dot and check mark.          


Given

User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.

 

When

Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" get enabled.

 

 

Given

Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE).

When

User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarms get shelved, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  


Given

User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.

When

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Un-shelve alarm" should be enabled.

 

Given

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Un-shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarms should get un-shelved, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE. 

 

Given

User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.

When

Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved"

( Alarm1 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" and "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled.

 

 

Given

Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)

When

User click on "Pause" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get paused.          

 

 

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE) 

When

User click on "Play (Un-pause)" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get un-paused.          

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state.

When

Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" get enabled.

 

Given

Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   

When

User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for shelve while pause. Selected alarms should be shelved only after un-pause and confirmation. 

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  


Given

Alarm list in pause state.

When

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Un-shelve alarm" should be enabled.

 

Given

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Un-shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for un-shelve while pause. selected alarms should be un-shelved only after un-pause and confirmation.  

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state.

When

Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved"( Alarm1 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" and "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled. 

 


Given

User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

When

User do mouse RIGHT KEY click on any alarm row. 

Then

Selected alarm rows should be un-selected. The alarm row on which mouse right key click is performed should get selected and context menu shall be presented as per the object in selected alarm row.     

 

Given

User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

When
User click some other places in browser.

Then
The behavior should be same as implemented for single alarm row selection.

Title: [Stretch] Alarm list | Alarm reshelving
Description:
Alarm list tool bar should have two separate buttons for shelving and un-shelving.


Prerequisite:

OC Alarm list subscribed to 800xA OPC UA Server and receiving new alarm for example 1 alarm/sec.   

OC Alarm list has multiple standing alarms, some acknowledged and some unacknowledged and some RTN. Alarms with ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ] , ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE/FALSE.   

Given

Alarm list with multiple alarms with different state. A user selects one or multiple alarm rows.

When

Selected alarms are with state "un-shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   

Then

Tool bar buttons “Shelve alarm” should be enabled and "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled.


Given

Selected alarms are with state "un-shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)

When

User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarms get shelved with selected shelve mode | SHELVE MODE | Standard | One-shot |, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  



Given

Alarm list with multiple alarms with different state. A user selects one or multiple alarm rows.

When

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar buttons “Shelve alarm” and "Un-shelve alarm" should be enabled.

 

Given

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarms get shelved with selected shelve mode | SHELVE MODE | Standard | One-shot |, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  


Given

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Un-Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Selected alarms gets un-shelved.

Given

Alarm list with multiple alarms having different state. A user selects multiple alarm rows.

When

Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved".

(Alarm1 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" should be enabled and button "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled.

 

Given

Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved".

(Alarm1 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarms get shelved with selected shelve mode | SHELVE MODE | Standard | One-shot |, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  

  

Given

Alarm list in pause state.

When

Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar buttons “Shelve alarm” and "Un-shelve alarm" both should be enabled.

 

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms are with state "shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for shelve while pause. Selected alarms should be shelved only after un-pause and confirmation. 

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms are with state "shelved" (ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Un-shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

On un-shelving selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for un-shelve while pause. Selected alarms should be un-shelved only after un-pause and confirmation. 

  

Given

Alarm list in pause state. A user selects multiple alarm rows.

When

Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved"(Alarm1 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   

Then

Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" should be enabled and button "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled.

 

Given

Alarm list in pause state. Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved".

(Alarm1 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)

When

User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.

Then

Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 

On shelving selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for shelve while pause. Selected alarms should be shelved only after un-pause and confirmation. Alarms get shelved with selected shelve mode | SHELVE MODE | Standard | One-shot |, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE

On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.

Title: CR 7.6a,b "Network and security configuration settings"
Description:
Requirement:

These configuration settings are the adjustable parameters of the control system components. By default the component should be configured to the recommended settings. In order for a component to detect and correct any deviations from the approved and/or recommended configuration settings, the component needs to support monitoring and control of changes to the configuration settings in accordance with security policies and procedures.

Title: CR 7.4 Control system recovery and reconstitution
Description:
Component recovery and reconstitution to a known secure state means that all system parameters (either default or configurable) are set to secure values, security-critical patches are reinstalled, security-related configuration settings are reestablished, system documentation and operating procedures are available, components are reinstalled and configured with established settings, information from the most recent, known secure backups is loaded and the system is fully tested and functional.

***Argument/Evidences:


Configuration has to be redeployed.

Title: SR-5918 NGT HMI Product Integration Testing
Description: This Epic covers various PIT and PTT activities of the 800xA 7.0xP0 release.

Title: CR 3.5 - Input validation
Description:
Rules for checking the valid syntax of input data such as set points should be in place to verify that this information has not been tampered with and is compliant with the specification. Inputs passed to interpreters should be pre-screened to prevent the content from being unintentionally interpreted as commands.  Note that this is a security CR, thus it does not address human error, for example supplying a legitimate integer number which is outside the expected range.  
Generally accepted industry practices for input data validation include out-of-range values for a defined field type, invalid characters in data fields, missing or incomplete data and buffer overflow. Additional examples where invalid inputs lead to system security issues include SQL injection attacks, cross-site scripting or malformed packets (as commonly generated by protocol fuzzers). Guidelines to be considered should include well-known guidelines such as the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Code Review Guide.

Title: Object Explorer Deploy Send files
Description:
Operations Client (OC) contains Object Explorer which needs Objectdirectory database to browse properties. The current deploy tool doesn't provide this Objectdirectory file to Object Explorer, therefore deploy tool needs to extend by adding Object Explorer Deploy Provider and sending the Objectdirectory to Object Explorer.
The deploy provider shall provide:
  • ObjectDirectory.db
  • ObjectDirectory2.db

Title: CR 3.4a Software & information integrity - Software, information & configuration
Description:
7.6.1 -  Requirement
Components shall provide the capability to perform or support integrity checks on software, configuration and other information as well as the recording and reporting of the results of these checks or be integrated into a system that can perform or support integrity checks.
7.6.2 - Rationale and supplemental guidance Integrity verification methods are employed to detect, record, report and protect against
software and information tampering that may occur if other protection mechanisms (such as authorization enforcement) have been circumvented. Components should employ formal or recommended integrity mechanisms (such as cryptographic hashes). For example, such mechanisms could be used to monitor field devices for their latest configuration information to
detect security breaches (including unauthorized changes).

Title: Security functionality verification
Description:
The product supplier and/or system integrator should provide guidance on how to test the designed security controls. Asset owners need to be aware of the possible ramifications of running these verification tests during normal operations. Details of the execution of these verifications need to be specified with careful consideration of the requirements for continuous
operations (for example, scheduling or prior notification).
Examples of security verification functions include:
• Verification of antivirus countermeasures by European Institute for Computer Antivirus Research (EICAR) testing of the control system file system. Antivirus software should detect the EICAR test samples and appropriate incident handling procedures should be triggered.
• Verification of the identification, authentication and use control countermeasures by attempting access with an unauthorized account (for some functionality this could be automated).
• Verification of intrusion detection systems (IDSs) as a security control by including a rule in the IDS that triggers on irregular, but known non-malicious traffic. The test could then be performed by introducing traffic that triggers this rule and the appropriate  IDS monitoring and incident handling procedures.
• Confirmation that audit logging is occurring as required by security policies and
procedures and has not been disabled by an internal or external entity.
***Argument/Evidences:

Feature is created to fulfill this requirement. Please refer WI https://dev.azure.com/ABB-BCI-PCP/PCP/_workitems/edit/242097

Title: CR 2.9 - Audit Storage Capacity - in context to containerized environment
Description:
***Argument/Evidences:
Audit storage is not in scope for Operation client scope. This needs to be taken care by system.

Title: CR 2.8 - Auditable events
Description:
Components shall provide the capability to generate audit records relevant to security for the following categories:
a) access control;
b) request errors;
c) control system events;
d) backup and restore event;
e) configuration changes; and
f) audit log events.
Individual audit records shall include:
a) timestamp;
b) source (originating device, software process or human user account);
c) category;
d) type;
e) event ID; and
f) event result.

***Argument/Evidences:

a) access control; [NA]
b) request errors; [Y]
c) control system events; [Y]
d) backup and restore event; [NA]
e) configuration changes; and [Y]
f) audit log events. [NA]

Audit records has all the fields included.
Windows event log is used for audit events for deploy function according to IEC specification. IdP audit events (Failed & Success login) are out of scope and is handled by engineering.

PG2 Write and alarm write operations uses the audit functionality of the 800xA OPC UA Server.

Please refer implementation feature below for more information:
https://dev.azure.com/ABB-BCI-PCP/PCP/_workitems/edit/43562


***Gap:

Auditing in context to containerized environment is missing. NGT OS recommendation is required to adhere to this requirement.

Title: CR 2.4 a,b,c & 2.4.1 - Mobile code security - control execution & transfer, integrity & authenticity verification context to containerized environment
Description:
Mobile code technologies include, but are not limited to, Java, JavaScript, ActiveX, portable document format (PDF), Postscript, Shockwave movies, Flash animations and VBScript.
Usage restrictions apply to both the selection and use of mobile code installed on servers and mobile code downloaded and executed on individual workstations. Control procedures should prevent the development, acquisition or introduction of unacceptable mobile code within the control system in which the component resides. For example, mobile code exchanges may be
disallowed directly within the control system, but may be allowed in a controlled adjacent environment maintained by IACS personnel. The use control requirements for mobile code are component-specific and can be located as requirements for each specific component type in Clauses 12 through 15.

***Argument/Evidences:

SAR 2.4a:
CSP headers are implemented which will prevent loading mobile code from untrusted sources. Content security policy is enforced to load mobile codes(JS, CSS, images etc.) from whitelisted source. ACL & Auditing is also implemented to handle the same for windows environment[<This needs to be investigated for containerized environment>].

The Operations Client downloads the javascripts, css and wasm (web assembly) files. The connection to the control system is done via a OPC UA Server from an Operations Client Backend services hosted in containerized environments.

Browser hardening & mobile code security is also recommended in hardening guide:
https://dev.azure.com/ABB-BCI-PCP/PCP/_wiki/wikis/Operations.HMI.Documentation/36713/Cybersecurity?anchor=mobile-code-security

SAR 2.4b:
CSP headers are implemented which will prevent loading mobile code from untrusted sources. Content security policy is enforced to load mobile codes(JS, CSS, images etc.) from whitelisted source. ACL & Auditing is also implemented to handle the same for windows environment, for containerized environment this needs to be investigated.[This needs to be investigated with NGT OS functions??]

The Operations Client downloads the JavaScript's, css and wasm (web assembly) files. The connection to the control system is done via a OPC UA Server from an Operations Client Backend services hosted in a containerized environments.

Only 800xA System Installer installs the Operations Client backend services in containerized environment. ACL & auditing enabled for folders & files holding mobile codes in the backend service in containerized environment [NGT OS functions to handle this??]. When a browser client request for the webpage after authentication, all the mobile code is served from this secure & trusted containerized environment.
SAR 2.4c:

Hashes for mobile codes maintained in pipelines but not distributed in media. Microsoft based libraries (WASM's loaded in browser) are also not designed to fulfill this requirement. Content Security Policy is defined to include JavaScript, images, CSS from only whitelisted sources. ACL & auditing enforced for folders where mobile code is present in the backend containerized environments. [NGT OS to confirm this???]
Also, browser hardening is recommended. There is no integrity validation for JS, typescript, CSS before executing in the browser.

Integrity verification for WASM in client side execution -> Discussed with Microsoft and they clarified that they are using this for checking if an update is needed. Not for security verification.

SAR 2.4.1:
For Mobile codes(JS, typescript etc. , WASM are the only mobile codes are there) we are not doing any  signing for that. However for microsoft based libraries, WASM are already signed with Microsoft signing however at the time of compilation for build optimization microsoft signature is removed, the WASM from Microsoft is not designed to fulfill requirement of integrity & Authenticity. Also, there is no hash validation for mobile codes at runtime, only hashes maintained in pipelines. ACL & auditing for files & folders modification is enforced both at Thin Client containerized environment. [NGT OS to fulfill this???]
CSP headers are enforced to validate source & data before execution in browser client.

Title: Faceplate | Faceplate Api to support view switching [Stretch]
Description:
Benefit\Background: Faceplate provides a way to interact with process for monitoring and controlling. Typically faceplates looks like an overlay that occupies real-estate within workplace, having fixed size occupying space is not desired. Hence, the idea of sizing the faceplates based on the content displayed was born. Typically there are 3 versions of size or view is designed having different contents based on real-estate namely reduced, standard, and extended.

Scope: Workplace faceplate interface mechanism shall provide a way to switch reduced, standard, and extended views based on user demands.
Note: Size and other parameters of the faceplate view shall be inherited from respective faceplate aspect type. Hence, it might be possible that there is a view such as standard with different size.

Out of Scope: Any other items that are not explicitly mentioned.

Related link if dependency to other features: Refer Links tab.

Title: Team Zena | Lab Improvement activities
Tags: ATDD:ACBinary; PI24.2; SPI24.2_committed; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready; Team Zena:DevOps
Description:
Background:
Team Zena's lab hosts an array of machines that operates using different Operating Systems such as Windows 10, Windows Server 2022, RHEL 9, and NGT OS 1. Recently lab monitoring capabilities were enhanced by adding Kubernetes Dashboard that helps users in daily troubleshooting activities and management of OC Cluster. Similarly, for better management of Windows machine we need proper maintenance and management practices in place, we aim to achieve this by having necessary GPOs and Domain Controllers in place.

Scope:
The life quality improvements for better troubleshooting of lab infrastructure shall be identified and addressed. The solution shall be easy and hassle free allowing quicker access to various VMs and better management of their checkpoints shall be in place.

Title: Trend | Common Lib | Knowledge Extractor Team Contributions
Tags: ATDD:ACBinary; PI24.2; SPI24.2_committed; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready; Team Zena: RegressionOnly
Description:
Background: Operator Trends are dynamic graphic displays that shows the progress of tag values with reference to time. The display presents the process values as a continuous line on an x, y graph/chart. The x-axis is referenced to time while y-axis is the value of the signal. Trending tag or object values are helpful to monitor process changes during the plant operations. NGT HMI project developed Trend component that is expected to be made as common library so that other projects within PCP project can make use of it. 

Scope: Feature #217572 created a opportunity to have contribution possibilities outside the NGT HMI. Knowledge Extractor team created many Usability Improvement functionalities to make better UX. Such usability functionalities shall be identified, and taken a contribution to newly created Trend's FE library.

Title: Team AJ QIP: Bug Leakage Reduction - Measure and Analyze

The activities to be covered in Measure phase and Analyze phase (Please plan to complete before end of PI24.2.3 to align with QIP timeline):

  1. Support for defining HMI test strategy (testers, Scrum Masters)
  2. Support for reviewing leaked bugs, planning team actions and proposing for project actions (all roles)
  3. Support for reviewing test cases with respect to test coverage (testers, POs)
  4. Support for reviewing if any elements/obstacles impacting test efficiency (testers, Scrum Masters)
  5. Support for reviewing current release process and timeline (POs, CMs, testers)
  6. Support for analyzing major causes of high bug leakage rate based on the output of Measure phase
  7. Support for other activities that may be brought up later

Title: CR 1.2 – Software process and device identification and authentication
Description:
5.4.1 Requirement 
Components shall provide the capability to identify itself and authenticate to any other
component (software application, embedded devices, host devices and network devices),
according to IEC 62443‑3‑3 SR1.2.
If the component, as in the case of an application, is running in the context of a human user,
in addition, the identification and authentication of the human user according to
IEC 62443‑3‑3 SR1.1 may be part of the component identification and authentication process
towards the other components.
5.4.2 Rationale and supplemental guidance
The function of identification and authentication is to map a known identity to an unknown
software process or device (henceforth referred to as an entity in 5.4.2) so as to make it
known before allowing any data exchange. Allowing rogue entities to send and receive control
system specific data can result in detrimental behaviour of the control system.
All entities should be identified and authenticated for all access to the control system.
Authentication of the identity of such entities should be accomplished by using methods such
as passwords, tokens or location (physical or logical). This requirement should be applied to
both local and remote access to the control system. However, in some scenarios where
individual entities are used to connect to different target systems (for example, remote vendor
support), it may be technically infeasible for an entity to have multiple identities. In these
cases, compensating countermeasures would have to be applied.
Special attention needs to be given when identifying and authenticating portable and mobile
devices. These types of devices are a known method of introducing undesired network traffic,
malware and/or information exposure to control systems, including otherwise isolated
networks.
Where entities function as a single group, identification and authentication may be role-based,
group-based or entity-based. It is essential that local emergency actions as well as control
system essential functions not be hampered by identification or authentication requirements
(see Clause 4 for a more complete discussion). For example, in common protection and
control schemes, a group of devices jointly execute the protection functions and communicate
with multicast messages among the devices in the group. In these cases, group authentication
based on shared accounts or shared symmetric keys are commonly used.



***Argument/Evidence:
Operation clients connects to 800xA OPC UA server with mTLS & JWT token based authentication  support. Operation client connects to Auth Server by referring to the endpoint url configured in backend services as application settings[Application setting files are secured through access control]. Operation client connects to CLS through JWT token based identification & authentication. All backend services related to OC [PG2, CM, trends , alarms] identified with client id. All the external services connect to OC through OPC UA with mTLS & JWT support , for https based communication JWT token identification/authentication is required.
***Gap:
Puneet Need to check with Christian whether 800xA strictly validating the authentication disallowing guest/anonymous. Is there a need to do that???

CLS utilization/integration of Auth server needs to be documented in architecture wiki. Epic/feature for implementation to be referred.

Certificate management/GDS integration needs to be discussed & confirmed. @Charles input required. Requirement implementation feature to be referred.

Title: CR 1.1 Human user identification & authentication - Auth Server utilization wiki missing
Description:
***Requirement description:

Components shall provide the capability to identify and authenticate all human users
according to IEC 62443‑3‑3 SR 1.1 on all interfaces capable of human user access. This
capability shall enforce such identification and authentication on all interfaces that provide
human user access to the component to support segregation of duties and least privilege in
accordance with applicable security policies and procedures. This capability may be provided
locally by the component or by integration into a system level identification and authentication
system.
NOTE Applicable security policies are a local matter.
5.3.2 Rationale and supplemental guidance
All human users need to be identified and authenticated for all access to the component.
Authentication of the identity of these users should be accomplished by using methods such
as passwords, tokens, biometrics or physically keyed lids, and in the case of multifactor
authentication, some combination thereof. The geographic location of human users can also
be used as part of the authentication process. This requirement should be applied to both
local and remote access to the component. This requirement comes in addition to the
requirement of having such an authentication and identification at the system level.
Interfaces capable of human user access are local user interfaces such as touchscreens,
push buttons, keyboards, as well as network protocols designed for human user interactions
such as hypertext transfer protocol (HTTP), HTTP secure (HTTPS), file transfer protocol
(FTP), secure FTP (SFTP), protocols used for device configuration tools (which are
sometimes proprietary and other times use open protocols). User identification and
authentication may be role-based or group-based (such as, for some component interfaces,
several users may share the same identity). User identification and authentication should not
hamper fast, local emergency actions.

***Argument/Evidence:

This requirement would be fulfilled with Auth Server utilization/integration. Operator users are the only human users who login into the OC & perform plant operations.
Please refer feature https://dev.azure.com/ABB-BCI-PCP/PCP/_workitems/edit/242023

***Gap:

The architecture wiki needs to be created to capture how OC would utilize the Auth Server for identification & authentication. Implementation feature to be created for adoption of this.

Title: CR 1.9 Strength of public key authentication - secure cipher/protocol & certificate/private key storage security gap
Description:
5.11.1 Requirement
For components that utilize public-key-based authentication, those components shall provide
directly or integrate into a system that provides the capability within the same IACS
environment to:
a) validate certificates by checking the validity of the signature of a given certificate;
b) validate the certificate chain or, in the case of self-signed certificates, by deploying leaf
certificates to all hosts that communicate with the subject to which the certificate is
issued;
c) validate certificates by checking a given certificate’s revocation status;
d) establish user (human, software process or device) control of the corresponding private
key;
e) map the authenticated identity to a user (human, software process or device); and
f) ensure that the algorithms and keys used for the public key authentication conform to 8.5.
5.11.2 Rationale and supplemental guidance
To meet the requirements in 5.11.1 does not necessarily require a real time connection to a
certificate authority. Alternative out-of-band methods may be used to meet the requirements
in 5.11.1. For example, a disconnected system could install and update certifications using
manual out-of-band processes.
Public/private key cryptography strongly depends on the secrecy of a given subject’s private
key and proper handling of the trust relationships. When verifying a trust between two entities
based on public key authentication, it is essential to trace the public key certificate to a
trusted entity. A common implementation error in certificate validation is to only check the
validity of a certificate’s signature, but not checking the trust in the signer. In a PKI setting, a
signer is trusted if they are a trusted CA or have a certificate issued by a trusted CA, thus all
verifiers need to trace certificates presented to them back to a trusted CA. If such a chain of
trusted CAs cannot be established, the presented certificate should not be trusted.
If self-signed certificates are used instead of a PKI, the certificate subject itself signed its
certificate, thus there never is a trusted third-party or CA. This should be compensated by
deploying the self-signed public key certificates to all peers that need to validate them via an
otherwise secured mechanism (for example, configuration of all peers in a trusted
environment). Trusted certificates need to be distributed to peers through secure channels.
During the validation process, a self-signed certificate should only be trusted if it is already
present in the list of trusted certificates of the validating peer. The set of trusted certificates
should be configured to the minimum necessary set.
In both cases, validation needs to also consider the possibility that a certificate is revoked. In
a PKI setting this is typically done by maintaining certificate revocation lists (CRLs) or running
an online certificate status protocol (OCSP) server. When revocation checking is not available
due to control system constraints, mechanisms such as a short certificate lifetime can
compensate for the lack of timely revocation information. Note that short lifetime certificates
can sometimes create significant operational issues in a control system environment.
It is expected that most components will integrate into an IACS and leverage the key
authentication mechanisms provided by the underlying IACS. When implementing public key
authentication at the component-level of an IACS, protection of the key becomes a primary
concern and objective of key storage on that component. Care should be taken in the
implementation to ensure that any private keys stored within the component cannot be
retrieved or tampered with (see 5.7).

***Argument/Evidences:
Requirement (a)  to  (c) & (e) to (f)  is fulfilled through utilization of  Certificate Management framework. For requirement (d) <Private keys for certificate for application & OPC UA server would be stored in Microshift secret & in PVC's  with ACL's in place>.

***Gap:

<Private keys for ingress TLS connection would be stored in Microshift secret service>???? this is a missing information, OPC UA secure connection certificate attributes (private key)  needs to be stored in PVC with ACL in place????. Latest TLS protocol [TLSv1.3] with secure cipher support is missing.

Title: CR 1.5c Authenticator Management  - JWT token management, client secret rotation
Description:
5.7.1 Requirement
Components shall provide the capability to:
a) support the use of initial authenticator content;
b) support the recognition of changes to default authenticators made at installation time;
c) function properly with periodic authenticator change/refresh operation; and
d) protect authenticators from unauthorized disclosure and modification when stored, used
and transmitted.
5.7.2 Rationale and supplemental guidance
In addition to an identifier (see 5.6) an authenticator is required to prove identity. Control
system authenticators include, but are not limited to, tokens, symmetric keys, private keys
(part of a public/private key pair), biometrics, passwords, physical keys and key cards. There
should be security policies in place instructing human users to take reasonable measures to
safeguard authenticators, including maintaining possession of their individual authenticators,
not loaning or sharing authenticators with others and reporting lost or compromised
authenticators immediately.
Authenticators have a lifecycle. When an account is created automatically a new authenticator
needs to be created, in order for the account owner to be able to authenticate. For example,
in a password-based system, the account has a password associated with it. Definition of the
initial authenticator content could be interpreted as the administrator defining the initial
password that the account management system sets for all new accounts. Being able to
configure these initial values makes it harder for an attacker to guess the password between
account creation and first account use (which should involve the setting of a new password by
the account owner). Some control systems are installed with unattended installers that create
all necessary accounts with default passwords and some embedded devices are shipped with
default passwords. Over time, these passwords often become general knowledge and are
documented on the Internet. Being able to change the default passwords protects the system
against unauthorized users using default passwords to gain access. Passwords can be
obtained from storage or from transmission when used in network authentication. The
complexity of this can be increased by cryptographic protections such as encryption or
hashing or by handshake protocols that do not require transmission of the password at all.
Still, passwords might be subject to attacks, for example, brute force guessing or breaking the
cryptographic protection of passwords in transit or storage. The window of opportunity can be
reduced by changing/refreshing the passwords periodically. Similar considerations apply to authentication systems based on cryptographic keys. Enhanced protection can be achieved
by using hardware mechanisms such as hardware security modules like trusted platform
modules (TPMs).
The management of authenticators should be specified in applicable security policies and
procedures, for example, constraints to change default authenticators, refresh periods,
specification of the protection of authenticators or firecall procedures.
Besides the capabilities for authenticator management specified in this requirement, the
strength of the authentication mechanism depends on the strength of the chosen authenticator
(for example, password complexity or key length in public key authentication) and the policies
for validating the authenticator in the authentication process (for example, how long a
password is valid or which checks are performed in public key certificate validation). For the
most common authentication mechanisms, password-based and public key authentication,
5.9, 5.10 and 5.11 provide further requirements.
Use of components for some operations may be restricted, requiring additional authentication
(such as tokens, keys and certificates) in order to perform some functions.

***Argument/Evidence:
We are relying on Auth Server for authenticator change/refresh operations. Password policy would be according to system requirement.

**Gap:

User account password managed at system level (Auth Server)  & for backend service [Configuration Manager service] client secret rotation needs to be provisioned through Auth Server. This require an investigation handling the same in containerized environment.

Title: Licensing | Adopt CLS implementation for JWT authentication
Description:
CLS is implementing the support for JWT authentication for the communication between "CLS Client Proxy" and "NGT component".    
Once CLS changes are available, new CLS nuget need to be integrated in Operations Client to pass token which can be authenticated by CLS in CLS Client Proxy. The CLS Server url need to be updated as required.  

Prerequisite: 
System 800xA 7.0 with required version of CLS (which support JWT Authentication) is installed.
The CLS Server url is updated as required.  
License file with OC license feature limited quantity (consider 5) is loaded.

When: 
Open OC workplaces and log in with valid users.
Then: 
Open CLS "License Assignment Editor". It shows that one quantity of OC license is consumed per opened OC workplaces.     

When: Close OC workplace
Then:  Open CLS "License Assignment Editor". It shows that quantity of OC license is released and count match as per opened OC workplaces.

When: log off in OC workplace
Then:  Open CLS "License Assignment Editor". It shows that quantity of OC license is released and count match as per opened OC workplaces.

Given: 
Number of OC workplaces opened and logged in are 5. Open CLS "License Assignment Editor". It shows that 5 OC license quantities are consumed.
When : 
Open and login 6th OC workplace. 
Then:
OC workplace shows insufficient license quantity violation.
When:
Pass invalid token along with license request. (for example Postman can be used).
Then    
License request is rejected with communication error.

Title: Event list | Performance requirements for xP0
Description:
Expectation is to enhance the stability and responsiveness of event list.
Event list should meet the required call up times as below:
Event List with 1000 events callup < 1 s
Event List 10000 events  callup < 2 s
Very large Event List with 100'000 events 5 s

Update Rate shall be less than 1 s

Requirement is to support 50 numbers of nodes simultaneously connected to an OC backend. Each node can access 2 event lists
- that means an backend should support at least 100 event list simultaneously. Also consider scalability for future volume requirements.

Title: Event list | Event subscription and history read as per deployed filter configuration
Description:
An Event list view should show events as per the filter configuration defined in data model exported from System 800xA using deploy tool and supported by OPC UA A&C client lib and 800xA OPC UA Server. 

It should be possible to open Event list from a Context Menu for an object/source as per the filter configuration defined in data model for that specific object/source.


Users should be able to open more than one Event list view's on same and/or different nodes.   


verify that different combination of filter configurations are supported. refer below screenshots for filter configurations

 





Considering OPC UA Server limitations in 6.2, functionality should be implemented as below for 6.2 Rollup.

WHEN 
Deployed configuration from 800xA has Time (View From, To) is set to Newest and Oldest.
THEN 

Default time scope should be set to 1 hour. (Configurable in app setting file). Start time will always current time (now). End time is current time less 1 hour.   

Default cache size 3000 (Configurable in app setting file), this is the maximum number of events that can be visualized on OC Event list for selected time scope. Event list should subscribe for new events and do history read to update cache with events in 1 hour time scope, number of events do not exceed cache size. Old events shall be discarded from cache if more than configured cache size.    

Event list shall be in un-paused (Play) state.

It should be possible to scroll through cached events.

Date Time picker (From, To) should be disabled and blank.




WHEN
Number of events in selected time are more than configured cache size.
THEN
Total number of events can should be shown in Event list = Configured cache size. 

Event list shows notification that not all events are displayed for selected time scope.
