Title: Alarm list | Support for multiple alarm row selection (CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY)
Description:
Alarm list should have ability to select multiple rows of alarms in an alarm list. It should be possible to show and perform common menu options on selected row of alarms. 


GIVEN
OC Alarm list subscribed to 800xA OPC UA Server and receiving new alarm for example 1 alarm/sec.   
OC Alarm list has multiple standing alarms, some acknowledged and some unacknowledged and some RTN
alarms with ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]
  
Use Case 1:
WHEN
User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

THEN
all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  

------ WHEN
          Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]   
User click on "Acknowledge alarm" button in tool bar.
------ THEN
selected alarms which are UNACK get Acknowledged. Selected alarm rows should get un-selected.      
          
------ WHEN
          Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]   
User click on "Acknowledge visible alarms" button in tool bar. Selected alarm rows should get un-selected.
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows gets unselected. all visible UNACK alarms get acknowledged.          

------ WHEN
Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]
Some selected alarm rows with ALARM_STATE = RTN-UNACK are acknowledged by other client, and got removed from alarm list view.
Some selected alarm rows with ALARM_STATE =  ACT-ACK become RTN, and got removed from alarm list view. 
------ THEN
Remaining selected alarm rows which are not removed from alarm list view should still stay selected. 

Use Case 2:
WHEN
User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

THEN
all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  

------ WHEN
          Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]   
User click on "Pause" button in tool bar.
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get paused.          

------ WHEN
          Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]   
User click on "Play (Un-pause)" button in tool bar. No alarm acknowledge is performed. 
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get un-paused.          

------ WHEN
          Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]   
User click on "Acknowledge alarm" button in tool bar.
------ THEN
ACK column of selected alarms which are with UNACK state get blue dot and check mark.      

------ WHEN
          Selected alarms has different states ALARM_STATE = [ ACT-UNACK, ACT-ACK, RTN-UNACK ]   
User click on "Acknowledge visible alarms" button in tool bar.
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows should stay selected. ACK column of all visible UNACK alarms get blue dot and check mark          


Use Case 3:
WHEN
User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

THEN
all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  

------ WHEN
Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   
------ THEN
Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" get enabled.

--------------- WHEN
User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.
--------------- THEN
Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 
On shelving selected alarms get shelved, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE
On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  

------ WHEN
Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   
------ THEN
Tool bar button "Un-shelve alarm" should be enabled.

--------------- WHEN
User click on "Un-shelve alarm" button in tool bar.
--------------- THEN
Selected alarms should get un-shelved, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE. 


------ WHEN
Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved"( Alarm1 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   
------ THEN
Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" should be enabled. Tool bar button "Un-shelve" should be disabled. (Note: This will be added as part of reshelving functionality. )
Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" and "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled.

--------------- WHEN (Note: This will be added as part of reshelving functionality. )
User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.
--------------- THEN
Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open.  Option "One -shot (shelve this occurrence of the alarm) should be disabled.   
On shelving selected alarms get shelved, ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE
On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.

Use Case 4:
WHEN
User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

THEN
all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  

------ WHEN
          Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   
User click on "Pause" button in tool bar.
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows should stay selected. Alarm list should get paused.          

------ WHEN
          Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   
User click on "Play (Un-pause)" button in tool bar.
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows should get unselected. Alarm list should get un-paused.          

------ WHEN
Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms are with state "not shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE)   
------ THEN
Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" get enabled.

--------------- WHEN
User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.
--------------- THEN
Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open. 
On shelving selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for shelve while pause. Selected alarms should be shelved only after un-pause and confirmation. 
On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  

------ WHEN
Alarm list in pause state. Selected alarms are with state "shelved" ( ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   
------ THEN
Tool bar button "Un-shelve alarm" should be enabled.

--------------- WHEN
User click on "Un-shelve alarm" button in tool bar.
--------------- THEN
Selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for shelve while pause. selected alarms should be un-shelved only after un-pause and confirmation.  


------ WHEN
Some selected alarms are with state "not shelved" and some with "shelved"( Alarm1 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = FALSE and Alarm2 with  ALARM_SHELVE_STATE = TRUE)   
------ THEN
Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" should be enabled. Tool bar button "Un-shelve" should be disabled. (Note: This will be added as part of reshelving functionality. )
Tool bar button "Shelve alarm" and "Un-shelve alarm" should be disabled. 

--------------- WHEN (Note: This will be added as part of reshelving functionality. )
User click on "Shelve alarm" button in tool bar.
--------------- THEN
Pop up window for shelve alarm should get open.  Option "One -shot (shelve this occurrence of the alarm) should be disabled.   
On shelving selected alarm rows follow use case as implemented for shelve while pause. Selected alarms should be shelved only after un-pause and confirmation. 
On cancel shelving, selected alarms still stay selected.  

Use Case 5:
WHEN
User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

THEN
all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  

------ WHEN
User do mouse RIGHT KEY click on any alarm row. 
------ THEN
Selected alarm rows should be un-selected. The alarm row on which mouse right key click is performed should get selected and context menu shall be presented as per the object in selected alarm row.     

Use Case 6:
WHEN
User keep pressed keyboard KEY = CTRL and mouse LEFT KEY click on multiple, random alarm rows on same page. Scroll in alarm list and click on some more random alarm rows. 

THEN
all the alarm rows which are clicked should get selected, HIGHLIGHT = BLUE.  

------ WHEN
User click some other places in browser.
------ THEN
          The behavior should be same as implemented for single alarm row selection.

Title: SR-3454 Operations Client FR7 xP0 Gaps
Description:
Resource availability

The aim of this series of CRs is to ensure that the component is resilient against various types
of DoS events. This includes the partial or total unavailability of component functionality at
various levels. In particular, security incidents in the component should not affect essential
functions or other safety-related functions.

Title: SR-3453 Operations Client FR6 xP0 Gaps
Description:
Timely response to events

Although a system may begin operation in a secure state, it is important to be able to monitor
the system to ensure that it remains in that secure state. If an event impacts the security of a
system, timely notification of the event may be critical to mitigating the associated risk. Asset
owners should establish security policies and procedures and proper lines of communication
and control needed to respond to security violations. Derived recommendations and
guidelines should include mechanisms that collect, report, preserve and automatically
correlate the forensic evidence to ensure timely corrective action. The use of monitoring tools
and techniques should not adversely affect the operational performance of the control system

Title: SR-3452 Operations Client FR5 xP0 Gaps
Description:
Restricted data flow



Using their risk assessment methodology defined in IEC 62443‑3‑2 [5], asset owners should determine necessary information flow restrictions and thus, by extension, determine the configuration of the conduits used to deliver this information. Derived recommendations and guidelines should include mechanisms that range from disconnecting control system networks from business or public networks to using unidirectional gateways, single stateful firewalls or DMZ configurations to manage the flow of information.

*** Argument/Evidences:

Need to discuss applicability of this requirement for component streams. We are documenting firewall rules however for 7.0 we need to investigate as we would have our ingress to be on port 443??? Is this something out of scope for component streams??? relying on system capability???

Title: SR-3451 Operations Client FR4 xP0 Gaps
Description:
Data confidentiality

  • Some component-generated information, whether at rest or in transit, is of a confidential or sensitive nature. This implies that some communication channels and datastores require protection against eavesdropping and unauthorized access.

Title: SR-3450 Operations Client FR3 xP0 Gaps
Description:
System integrity

Components often go through multiple testing cycles (unit testing, system testing, etc.) before they begin production to establish that the components will perform as intended before they even begin production. Once operational, asset owners are responsible for maintaining the integrity of the component. Using their risk assessment methodology, asset owners may assign different levels of integrity protection to different components, communication channels
and information in their IACS. The integrity of physical assets should be maintained in both operational and non-operational states, such as during production, when in storage or during a maintenance shutdown. The integrity of logical assets should be maintained while in transit and at rest, such as being transmitted over a network or when residing in a data repository

Title: SR-3449 Operations Client FR2 xP0 Gaps
Description:
Use control:

Once the user is identified and authenticated, the component should restrict the allowed
actions to the authorized use of the component. Asset owners and system integrators will
have to assign, to each user (human, software process or device), group, role, etc. (see 4.5),
the privileges defining the authorized use of the component. The goal of use control is to
protect against unauthorized actions on the component’s resources by verifying that the
necessary privileges have been granted before allowing a user to perform the actions.
Examples of actions are reading or writing data, downloading programs and setting
configurations. Recommendations and guidelines should include mechanisms that will operate
in mixed modes. For example, some component resources require strong use control
protection, such as restrictive privileges, and others do not. By extension, use control
requirements should be extended to data at rest. User privileges may vary based on time-ofday/
date, location and means by which access is made.

Title: SR-3447 Operations Client FR1 xP0 Gaps
Description:
**Requirement:

Identify and authenticate all users (humans, software processes and devices), prior to allowing them access to the system or assets.

Identification of users is used in conjunction with authorization mechanisms to implement
access control for a component. Verifying the identity of users requesting access is necessary
to protect against unauthorized users from gaining access to the component.
Recommendations and guidelines should include mechanisms that will operate in mixed
modes. For example, some components on a communication channel require strong access
control, such as strong authentication mechanisms, and others do not. By extension, access
control requirements need to be extended to data at rest.
It is recommended that the number of identification and authentication mechanisms within a
single zone is minimized. The use of multiple identification and authentication mechanisms
makes the task of authentication and identification management more difficult to administer.

Title: SR-5918 NGT HMI 24.1 Release Activities
Description: This Epic covers release-related activities at the end of each iteration. A build is created, including build notes, documentation, etc. Necessary tests are executed.

Title: Define cybersecurity testing strategy - security functionality verification
Description:
Define a strategy for security functionality verification of NGT HMI deliverables. The following test areas have to be considered:
  1. Authentication verification (default deny) : Verify if authentication is enforced for all interfaces (REST API) & User interfaces. Validate by checking if interfaces accessible (post login pages & authenticated interfaces endpoint) without authentication.
  2. Authorization verification for user roles by validating if one user role has access to functionality of different user role. Verification of the identification, authentication and use control countermeasures by attempting access with an unauthorized account.
  3. ACL file/folder verification – Validate file folder permissions set correctly.
  4. Logging & auditing – Verify whether logging & auditing is working as implemented. App logs, windows auditing & logging getting recorded with required attributes.
  5. AV scan with at least 3 antivirus engines.
  6. Account lockout functionality verification  also procedure to check how account unlock would be achieved for critical functions (Disaster Recovery functionality verification).
  7. Wrong credential input notification verification.
  8. Encryption & hashing functionality working as defined by security requirements.
  9. Verify Firewall rules are working as expected only port 443 getting  utilized/invoked by NG HMI.
  10. Verify request throttling control.
  11. Redundancy verification.
  12. Verification of Service functionality in event of crash or network unavailability.
  13. Verification of audit log failure to critical functions.
  14. User session expiration & lock feature. Logout functionality to validate all sessions invalidated.
  15. Backend service crash & restart in fail secure manner -  validation.
  16. Connection interruption test cases.
  17. Input boundary validation, malformed input.
  18. Activities creates logs, could it be feasible to create a test case to validate if sensitive information should not get logged. App logs or any other logs created.
For each of the above points an approach is agreed on and a feature is planned for each team (if applicable) to implement the verification into their test plan. It is possible that some test cases will be tested automatically and some might require manual test. For the automatic test cases it shall be determined if they will be executed at component level by teams or at product level as part of a smoke / regression test.

Title: Merge 2.1 Documentation to 3.0 and Improve the content
Description:
Benefit/Background:: User documentation are integral part of any product and plays vital role in making successful product. It helps in easily onboarding users and overcome initial learning curve by providing detailed insights into every features Operations Client and System 800xA. Effective user documentation serves as a valuable sales tool, showcasing the Operations Client features and benefits. Also, helps users quickly understand how to use the product which can increase Operations Client Adoption.

In general, updated documents with known techniques like 5W, and 1H which helps in effective technical writing. Missing such writing methods leads to poor readability and not covering all aspects of user documentation.

Scope: Overall review of the documentation shall be carried out and improvement areas shall be identified, and addressed resulting to better readability of the user documentation.

Out of Scope: New functionality developed in PI 24.3, only covers existing content from 2.1

Related link if dependency to other features: Refer Links tab.

Title: Team Sierra QIP: Bug Leakage Reduction - Improve
Description:
HMI has two outstanding quality issues: high number of bugs and high bug leakage rate (about 24% bugs are reported in SIT and STT phases). A QIP is initiated with the methodology of L6S-DMAIC to tackle with the two issues. The project is planned to be completed in 2 PIs and will cover the activities of 5 DMAIC phases: Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control, with which to introduce effective and efficient practices and optimize current test process, aiming to reduce bug inflow speed and lower bug leakage rate.

In PI24.1, plan to finish first three DMAIC phases, and activities include
  • Defining main quality issues to be addressed and set target with RO and QIP team
  • Measuring the current statuses of these issues with the support of HMI teams
  • Analyzing critical root causes and come up with actions to eliminate or mitigate root causes 
  • Implementing improvements of high priority agreed by HMI teams 
In PI24.2, plan to finish the last two DMAIC phases, and activities include
  • Implementing Improve actions agreed in PI24.1
  • Documenting new process if necessary
  • Monitoring the optimized process and practices to Control the outcome
  • Providing periodical retrospective data to stakeholders for further adjustment

Title: SR-5918 QIP: Bug Leakage Reduction
Description:
The target for this QIP is to reduce HMI bug leakage rate from 21.6% (in OC 2.0) to 11% (for OC 3.0 bugs till end of this QIP). And the long-term target is to keep HMI bug leakage rate at a low level to reduce the time, efforts and cost caused by late bug detection. You can find more details of the QIP here: https://abb.sharepoint.com/:p:/r/teams/NGTHMIBugLeakageReduction/Shared%20Documents/General/NGT%20HMI%20Bug%20Leakage%20Reduction.pptx?d=w97ebae0c0a814515b2b364d7b4562b5b&csf=1&web=1&e=qfleb8

 

According to Software Development | PCP R&D QMS (abb.com), the main activities for software development include Design, Code, Build & Test, and Integrate. Relevant activities are Requirement, documentation, etc..

 

To find out the major causes for high bug leakage rate, we will not limit our focus on Test only. Requirement, development, release, documentation…, most of the activities in software development cycle will be reviewed and analyzed, and shall be improved if they are agreed as major causes that contributing to high bug leakage rate.

 

The activities to be covered in Measure phase and Analyze phase:

  1. Support for defining HMI test strategy (testers, Scrum Masters)
  2. Support for reviewing leaked bugs, planning team actions and proposing for project actions (all roles)
  3. Support for reviewing test cases with respect to test coverage (testers, POs)
  4. Support for reviewing if any elements/obstacles impacting test efficiency (testers, Scrum Masters)
  5. Support for reviewing current release process and timeline (POs, CMs, testers)
  6. Support for analyzing major causes of high bug leakage rate based on the output of Measure phase
  7. Support for other activities that may be brought up later

 

The activities to be covered in Improve phase:

  1. Support for action planning to address the major causes figured out in Analyze phase
  2. Make sure all agile teams are following HMI test strategy
  3. Make sure all agile teams have implemented planned actions

The activities to be covered in Control phase:

  1. Adopt a visualized and efficient way for polling and monitoring key data
  2. Periodical review of key data
  3. Continuous improvement process in place

Title: Context menu integrates new Object Directory
Description:
Background: The Object Directory is a component which is responsible of storing and providing access to the common information about the system. Such as Objects, References (structures) and meta data about Models (equivalent to Aspects in System800xA). The Object Directory is a core component that bounds the "functionality oriented" HMI BE Services in the system together and allow them to have a common understanding of the system. A new version of Object Directory Interface being introduced in step wise manner, one focusing method calls and structures. Another focusing on Navigational changes and cross-referencing.

Scope: Investigate and integrate changed object directory interface/methods call in Context Menu and adopt new structures. New changes shall be carried analyzing impacts so that possible regression shall be contained.

Note: 
Reference about Object Directory. Object directory contracts


Major changes to Object Directory are made which need to be integrated for context menu.

Title: Team Zena | Base Container Image Alignment [Stretch]
Tags: PI24.1; Stretch; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready
Description:
Background: Container base image is an empty first layer which facilitates developer to build docker image as per their needs from scratch. Base image provides full control over the contents of image. As per the decision at NGT project level, RedHat's Universal Base Image (UBI) container shall be used.

Scope: Team Zena containers shall be updated to be base the RedHat Universal Base Image (UBI).

Note: An example Dockerfile on how to apply this on .NET images is included here:

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0 AS build

ARG VSS_NUGET_URI_PREFIXES
ENV VSS_NUGET_URI_PREFIXES=$VSS_NUGET_URI_PREFIXES
ARG VSS_NUGET_ACCESSTOKEN
ENV VSS_NUGET_ACCESSTOKEN=$VSS_NUGET_ACCESSTOKEN
ARG VSS_NUGET_EXTERNAL_FEED_ENDPOINTS
ENV VSS_NUGET_EXTERNAL_FEED_ENDPOINTS=$VSS_NUGET_EXTERNAL_FEED_ENDPOINTS

RUN curl -s -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Microsoft/artifacts-credprovider/master/helpers/installcredprovider.sh | bash

WORKDIR /routingservice

# copy csproj and restore as distinct layers
COPY src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service.csproj ./src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service/
COPY Directory.Build.props ./
COPY src/Directory.Build.props ./src/
COPY NuGet.config ./
RUN dotnet restore ./src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service -r linux-x64

# copy and publish app and libraries
COPY . ./
RUN dotnet publish ./src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service -c Release -o /app -r linux-x64 --self-contained true --no-restore

# change permissions to be able to run as non root user
RUN chmod -R +rx /app

# final stage/image
FROM registry.access.redhat.com/ubi9/ubi-minimal:9.2
ENV \
    # Configure web servers to bind to port 8080 when present
    ASPNETCORE_URLS=http://+:8080 \
    # Enable detection of running in a container
    DOTNET_RUNNING_IN_CONTAINER=true \
    DOTNET_SYSTEM_GLOBALIZATION_INVARIANT=1 \
    DOTNET_SSL_CERT_DIR=/opt/app-root/ssl_dir \
    # Enable Dynamic PGO
    DOTNET_TieredPGO=1 \
    DOTNET_TC_QuickJitForLoops=1 \
    DOTNET_ReadyToRun=0

WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=build /app .

ENTRYPOINT ["./ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service"]

Title: Trend | Trim Curve | Contribution to Trim Curve Implementation Finalization
Tags: PI24.1; SPI24.1_committed; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready
Description:
Background:
Operating any dynamic process is a difficult cognitive process and operators have to work with thousands numbers, status indications that is spread out over dozens of graphics, thus the need of High Performance HMI. One of the key way to handle such process data is to understand how data is approaching or direction of the data so that it helps the operator to understand the details such as rate of changes, possible future trend line, etc., The trend lines are superimposed on top of a graph w.r.t to amplitude of the data and time. The trend lines are plotted based on various data sources, typically historical and real-time. The trend chart is divided into the two portions to visualize both of these data. Real-time based plotting is also known as trim curves which typically shows more samples in comparison with historical data. Typically when a trend group is launched for a time scope, availability of signal values are expected to be from Historical data source failing such shall automatically redirected the signal value acquisition using OPC UA DA interface, which is in other words to be trim curves since they're present as long as trend group is kept opened and lost if refreshed or navigated out.

Scope: Trim curve functionality is being implemented by Team AJ using #199411, Team Zena is required to contribute on demand in terms of reviewing PRs, design reviews etc. This feature in general acts a placeholder item to track all contributions and support activities extended to Team AJ in completing trim curve implementation.

Title: Object Explorer | Tree Menu | Facilitate Aspect Type node as Object's leaf
Tags: PI24.2; SPI24.2_committed; Team Zena: Ready; Team Zena: RegressionOnly; Team Zena: Risk
Description:
Background: Menu and toolbar play vital role in Operator Workplace and user experience. Typically this is the first thing that the operator looks for in a Operator workplace and well-designed and contextual menu which is simplified in nature makes navigation quicker and faster. Hence, It is important to make any menu system quicker and faster, one the way to avoid multiple clicks to go to desired navigation, the flyout are typically a page menu that visually generates hierarchy menu (incl. parent and child) that flys out when user hover over it or clicking using standard interactions methods such as mouse hoover or right click. Alternatively, the flyout also known as Tree-menu where the invoking method from user might be different. Tree structure in Object explorer inherits Control structure thus helping Operator to visualize the Controller, Communication Interface Modules, IO modules, and Its associated Input/Output channels in a organized manner. In general helps them to organize, access and understand relationships among them. Object explorer by UI/UX definition is divided in two main component, the left side view being Tree Menu display inherited items of Control Structure and right side view displaying properties of selected object/tag from the tree.  The responsibility of object explorer view is split among Team Zena and Team AJ, where Zena responsible for Tree menu, and AJ is for property viewing.

Scope:
The following aspect types to be supported as object's leaf for any given structure along with existing aspect types such as PG2 graphics, Alarm List, Event List, and Trends.
  • Function Block
  • Control Module
  • Application
  • General Properties
  • Scripting aspect
  • Property Translation
  • Property Calculation
For all of the above Aspect types the default action shall be to launch Object Explorer to display their properties.
Where as for PG2, Alarm List, Event List and Trends their respect application shall be launched.

Note: No action shall take place at object level.

Title: Trend | Common Lib | Create Lib Based on NGT HMI Trend Component
Tags: IN; PI24.1; SPI24.1_committed; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready; Team Zena: RegressionOnly
Description:
Background: Operator Trends are dynamic graphic displays that shows the progress of tag values with reference to time. The display presents the process values as a continuous line on an x, y graph/chart. The x-axis is referenced to time while y-axis is the value of the signal. Trending tag or object values are helpful to monitor process changes during the plant operations. NGT HMI project developed Trend component that is expected to be made as common library so that other projects within PCP project can make use of it. 

Scope: Carve out the Frontend portion of current NGT HMI Trend component to be separate Common Lib that can be used across different PCP projects including NGT HMI. Once it's carved out the same Library shall be consumed back into NGT HMI. Such common library of trend frontend shall be accessible to other contributors across ABB who are subject to project level agreement with NGT HMI Project and it's contribution model. The library shall be NPM package and version management defined. Common Trend repo shall be integrated with Sonarqube and shall follow the PCP's functional process of a repo management.

Title: Container | Injecting/Hosting Common HMI chart into Operations Client
Tags: PI24.2; SPI24.2_committed; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready; Team Zena: RegressionOnly
Description:
Background: Helm chart typically is a collection of pre-configured orchestration platforms' resource files (set of YAML files). Basically, allocating resources required to run NGT services. It provides a standardized way to package and distribute applications/services in platforms such as Kubernetes. NGT HMI uses Common HMI as hosting technology which means uses its Helm chart definitions. These definitions shall be injected into NGT HMI's Operations Client YAML.


Scope: Common HMI's Hosting container's Chart definitions shall be inserted into NGT HMI's Operations Client YAML. Configuration values.yaml of the Operations Client chart needs to be adapted accordingly. CommonHMI can be enabled only through the enabling of a specific parameter via InstallationScripts: the purpose usage is only for development activities; no test can be done with enabled commonHMI

Title: Container | Secret Manager Investigation and PoC [Stretch]
Description:
Background: Secret management in container environment involves the secure and efficient handling of sensitive informations such as credentials and different keys. This is to enhance the security and ensure information is not exposed unintentionally. 

Scope: Reference: Secrets Management | Conjur, reference secret management in container environment shall be evaluated and such usage in secret management shall be demonstrated using PoC to seek early feedbacks and shortcomings.

Title: Container | Integration of GDS/LCS
Description:
Background: LCS is identified to be used for Windows deployments for System 800xA 6.2 (supporting IIS HTTPS certificates, registering windows-based OPC UA Servers with GDS, and acting as pull agent for Windows based OPC UA Clients). For kubernetes containers, HTTPS/TLS certificates shall be managed through cert-managers/Ingress to avoid using LCS in containerized environments. So, instead pull or push, cert-manager would create the certificates for containerized OPC UA components, store them as Kubernetes secrets, and expose them to the containers as a volume. The following figure depicts the current proposal from System Architects;



Scope: Cert-Manager shall be used for certificates needs. Means creating certificates, storing them as secrets, and exposing them to containers as volume.

Note: Cert-manager reference.

Title: Container | Switch to NGT OS
Tags: PI24.2; SPI24.2_committed; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: Ready; Team Zena: RegressionOnly
Description:
Background: Container orchestration are essential to manage and scale containerized application effectively. While Operating system is fundamental component including container orchestration. They're need for better management of resources, isolation of process, facilitating networking, providing required security, managing the storage, etc., Edgenius OS/NGT OS is identified/declared to be common OS platform for NGT projects.

Scope: Cluster OS shall be moved to Edgenius OS/NGT OS.

Title: Container | Installation script for microShift environment [No Integration with System 800xA Installer and NO Uninstallation]
Description:
Background: Currently container orchestration in microShift installation involves manual steps which involves user inputs of different configuration parameters. User experience of installation is affected due to this, it shall be possible to improve User experience by automatic the installation steps.

Scope: Provide methods to automate container installation steps for microShit environment. There shall be no direct dependency created with orchestration platform so that any future change of direction in orchestration platform change shall be addressed with minimal or no changes in such method of automated installation. In general, all steps described in section https://dev.azure.com/ABB-BCI-PCP/PCP/_wiki/wikis/Operations%20Stream/41095/MicroShift-Deployment?anchor=install-and-configure-microshift shall be automated. Update scenario shall be considered into scope.

Out of Scope: Installation of microShift since this is considered as prerequisite. Un-installation is not considered as well in PI 24.1.
Note: Due to the fact that currently no cadence established between System 800xA and NGT HMI projects, in terms of release alignment and management, no integration of such automated method with System 800xA's system installer shall taken up.

Reference: 

MicroShift Deployment - Overview (azure.com)

The following figure depicts the current proposal from System Architects;



Scope: Cert-Manager shall be used for certificates needs. Means creating certificates, storing them as secrets, and exposing them to containers as volume.

Scope: This is a placeholder feature to track all possible improvement activities carried out in Containers. The following topics are identified and it shall be addressed.

  • Remove cluster_ip from host file and verify results
  • DNS management. Host name being inserted manually, such as System 800xA. DNS IP

SR-5879 NGT HMI Common Base Containers
Description:
All NGT HMI containers should be based on RedHat Universal Base Image (UBI). An example Docker file on how to apply this on .NET images is included here:

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0 AS build

ARG VSS_NUGET_URI_PREFIXES
ENV VSS_NUGET_URI_PREFIXES=$VSS_NUGET_URI_PREFIXES
ARG VSS_NUGET_ACCESSTOKEN
ENV VSS_NUGET_ACCESSTOKEN=$VSS_NUGET_ACCESSTOKEN
ARG VSS_NUGET_EXTERNAL_FEED_ENDPOINTS
ENV VSS_NUGET_EXTERNAL_FEED_ENDPOINTS=$VSS_NUGET_EXTERNAL_FEED_ENDPOINTS

RUN curl -s -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Microsoft/artifacts-credprovider/master/helpers/installcredprovider.sh | bash

WORKDIR /routingservice

# copy csproj and restore as distinct layers
COPY src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service.csproj ./src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service/
COPY Directory.Build.props ./
COPY src/Directory.Build.props ./src/
COPY NuGet.config ./
RUN dotnet restore ./src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service -r linux-x64

# copy and publish app and libraries
COPY . ./
RUN dotnet publish ./src/ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service -c Release -o /app -r linux-x64 --self-contained true --no-restore

# change permissions to be able to run as non root user
RUN chmod -R +rx /app

# final stage/image
FROM registry.access.redhat.com/ubi9/ubi-minimal:9.2
ENV \
    # Configure web servers to bind to port 8080 when present
    ASPNETCORE_URLS=http://+:8080 \
    # Enable detection of running in a container
    DOTNET_RUNNING_IN_CONTAINER=true \
    DOTNET_SYSTEM_GLOBALIZATION_INVARIANT=1 \
    DOTNET_SSL_CERT_DIR=/opt/app-root/ssl_dir \
    # Enable Dynamic PGO
    DOTNET_TieredPGO=1 \
    DOTNET_TC_QuickJitForLoops=1 \
    DOTNET_ReadyToRun=0

WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=build /app .

ENTRYPOINT ["./ABB.IA.Edge.Router.Service"]

Title: Object Directory - Optimize and Finalize
Description:
The content of the object directory should be possible to be created from a S+ deploy tool. Meaning that no private aspect data can be read when extracting data from the ObjectDirectory (as structure nodes in SNS) and also any nuget/dlls:s necessary to create the database from a S+ deploy tool needs to be available for them.

Furthermore we should remove unnecessary aspects from being deployed, either by whitelisting what we know is needed or black listing some common unnecessary aspects.

Title: SR-5965 Internal Diagnostics properties w.r.t Node & Operation client Services
Description:
Each component of Operations Client exposes diagnostic data as per 209504 Diagnostic data for NGT components
New via OPC UA Server. This data will be subscribed and visualized by SMT. 

The CPU/memory consumption diagnostics isn’t needed for Operations, only service status diagnostic information of each Operations Client components is needed for Operations.

NGT runtime services’ diagnostics could be monitored via NGT OS, which is not in this OPC UA Server library scope.

Title: Workplace | Common HMI enabling [Stretch]
Tags: PI24.2; Stretch; Team Zena: DoR; Team Zena: RegressionOnly
Description:
Background: Currently Windows Manager is working both as the main site of the Operations Client web app and as a microservice for navigation/licensing/context menu. To reach the target solution, the CommonHMI should functionally replace completely the Windows Manager Frontend part, becoming the main site of the Operations Client web application.


Scope: The Workplace should adopt Common HMI Backend together with its configuration capabilities. The configuration shall be managed in the following 3 ways:

  • Configuration (Backup endpoint): Additional json file with default Backup json file sent by Deploy Tool. Configuration Manager shall be adapted to receive an additional json file in the zip file exclusively dedicated to CommonHMI Backup endpoint (new HTTPClient call interface). (Managed in features Feature 239942: Deploy Tool | Backup Payload Packing - Boards (azure.com) and Feature 239949: Configuration Manager | Common HMI Configuration Through Backup - Boards (azure.com))
  • Apps: Usage of CRDs as explained in the following link: PCP.CommonHMI/docs/deployment-manual/Deploying-applications.md at main · ABB-PA/PCP.CommonHMI (github.com)
  • Plugins: Using 2 options,
    • CRDs usage like apps
    • CTL as it is already working (Temp. solution, needs to be fully replaced by CRDs).

Specifically, the CommonHMI Frontend shall be able to open the existing components available in the current implementation, listed below:

  • WM Services
    • Api (service that manages backend interface)
    • Blink (blink service)
    • Config
    • Context-Menu
    • Gesture
    • License
    • NGTOperationsOverlay
    • Workplace
  • WM Plugins:
    • Drawer
    • TreeViewDrawer
    • WorkplacePlugin
    • CrossTabSessionManagement
    • DisableContextMenu
    • DisableUserMenu

Title: SR-5913 NGT 800xA Alarm List Performance
Description:
Expectation is to enhance the stability and responsiveness of alarm list.
   
Alarm list should meet the required call up times as below:
- Standard alarm list with 100 standing alarms callup < 1 s
- Large alarm list with 1000 standing alarms callup < 1.5 s
- Very large alarm list with 100'000 standing alarms 5 s
Update Rate shall be less than 1 s

Requirement is to support 50 numbers of nodes simultaneously connected to an OC backend. Each node can access 2 alarm lists, each having 5 new alarms each 20s, 50 standing alarms.
- that means an alarm list backend should support at least 100 alarm list simultaneously. Also consider scalability for future volume requirements.    


Below readiness requirements need to be complete to achieve the targeted performance for OC Alarm list.
- SR-4371 800xA OPC UA Server Performance improvements.
- SR-4373 800xA OPC UA Server AE support for subscribing to lists and filtering

Title: SR-5914 NGT 800xA Event List Performance
Description:
Expectation is to enhance the stability and responsiveness of event list.
Event list should meet the required call up times as below:
Event List with 1000 events callup < 1 s
Event List 10000 events  callup < 2 s
Very large Event List with 100'000 events 5 s

Update Rate shall be less than 1 s

Requirement is to support 50 numbers of nodes simultaneously connected to an OC backend. Each node can access 2 event lists
- that means an backend should support at least 100 event list simultaneously. Also consider scalability for future volume requirements.    


Below readiness requirements need to be complete to achieve the targeted performance for OC Event list.
- SR-4371 800xA OPC UA Server Performance improvements.
- SR-4373 800xA OPC UA Server AE support for subscribing to lists and filtering 
- SR-6773 Support historized events from 800xA OPC UA Server A&C

  • Port management between dedicated range
  • Secret management is going to be based on Kubernetes secrets as confirmed by System Architects and approved by CS team
  • CommonHMI FE/BE integration

If containers will be modified it shall be considered that we will be moving to a common base image in #217168.

The installation script will be called by System Installer (in the future) and it will deploy and configure OC on MicroShift node. We are assuming that OC and kubectl will be available on the node.

Title: KE UX | Markers
Description:
Marker Description
Markers in a trend chart have the goal to highlight a certain region of the trend chart. Like this, the trend chart user should be visually guided to a certain range of the trend chart.
A marker is basically a time range on at least one (or multiple) process variables to be highlighted.

For a system, there are different complications that need to be so considered in the UX design:
1) Multiple markers in the same screen: How should the system treat multiple active markers - by assigning different colors, by activating/highlighting only one and fading out others based on e.g. mouse movement.
2) Overlapping markers: How should the system treat markers that are 
3) 


Marker Visualization:


Marker Configuration:
Markers can be added by providing the value(s) in the trend chart element’s property called markers with such structure:
markers = [{
    area: {
        startTime: Date,
        endTime: Date
    },
    border: true/false
    color: rgb/hex/string
   opacity: between 0-1
}]




Background: Knowledge Extractor team developed set of Trend's Frontend features that we would like to consume in NGT HMI. However these features are not inline with NGT HMI UX definitions.

Title: UX for Alarm Shelving
Description:
Alarm shelving allows the operators to temporarily remove standing or nuisance alarms from the main alarm list and places it on the shelve list.
The required configuration for shelving is from config file for now.
Shelving Enabled, 
Shelving Time - selectable list of shelving times.
Shelving Reasons - selectable list of reasons.

Alarm list should have tool bar button for shelving. Which will be enabled if below points are true
- Shelving functionality is enabled.
- license for Shelving is available for system
- Alarm is selected in an Alarm list view.

Button should give shelve/unshelve option based on Alarm state (not shelved/shelved) of selected alarm.

Below are the parameters need to provide while shelving an alarm. A popup window is required which can allow operator to enter these parameters.

Shelving configuration defines how operators can shelve the alarms. There are two ways
to shelve the alarms:
– Standard Shelving.
Standard shelving allows the operators to shelve the alarms temporarily for a
specified time. Recurrences of the alarm because of a state change will not appear
in the main list until the specified time has elapsed.
– One-shot Shelving.
One-shot shelving will place the alarm in the shelf only once. When the state of the
alarm changes, the alarm is automatically removed from the shelf. Further instances
of the alarm will appear in the main list.

– Shelving Time.
Shelving time indicates the maximum time allowed for an alarm before the alarm is
removed from the shelf. System administrators can add or remove shelving times
from the list according to the plant specifications.

- Shelving Reasons.
Operators can select a shelving reason from the list of reasons provided.

Title: Workplace | Tree navigation
Description:
Background: Menu and toolbar play vital role in Operator Workplace and user experience. Typically this is the first thing that the operator looks for in a Operator workplace and well-designed and contextual menu which is simplified in nature makes navigation quicker and faster. Hence, It is important to make any menu system quicker and faster, one the way to avoid multiple clicks to go to desired navigation, the flyout are typically a page menu that visually generates hierarchy menu (incl. parent and child) that flys out when user hover over it or clicking using standard interactions methods such as mouse hoover or right click. Alternatively, the flyout also known as Tree-menu where the invoking method from user might be different.

Scope: 

In addition to the functionality implemented and delivered by #140832, the overlay navigation support shall be added.

Out of Scope: Tree navigation and doesn't support multiple browser windows.

Predecessor: System 800xA Deploy Tool to be ready and tree navigation info is included in the workplace DB. Unable to link the WI from OCS collection, hence mentioning here as text.

As we're planning to adapt CommonHMI 5.x which is expected to add more and functionalities in view management in workplace, it is necessary to include multi-view support for trend application.

Title: NGT ThinClient | Pop-up windows handling Step 2 (NO Multi Overlay)
Description:
Background: Faceplates are used by the operator and supervisors to monitor, interact, and control plant devices that are part of a process. Typically each plant devices is identified by a Id which is also known as Tag or Object name, such devices in a system consist of information that used for its monitoring and control it. In general faceplates provides a capability to operator to interact, control, and supervise the associated devices. Typically faceplates of an object can be launched by,
  • Click on graphical element in a graphic.
  • Click on hot-spot in a display
  • Click on Control/Faceplate option in Context that might be invoked from graphic, trend, alarm list, and event list.
In general, faceplates share common attributes with respect to their design and operation. However, depending upon their object type, and control application they belong to defines the functionality provided within the faceplate to meet their operational needs.

Scope: This features is expected to design and development of an overlay for faceplate support. It is expected that an overlay as faceplate shall be launched for an object location in a PG2 graphics, trend, and alarm list. The faceplate overlay shall provide following functionalities,
  1. It shall be possible to launch faceplates with pin or unpin mode.
  2. The size and position management shall be user configurable or managed by the object that calling the overlay.
  3. It support dragging around within the workplace subject to avoiding overlapping with safe area.
  4. It shall be possible to resize the overlay window.
Note: Any scope that is not described in the scope section are considered to be out of scope of this feature.

Title: CommonHMI 2.x | Alarm List Frontend Adoption

Title: Trend Cont. | Investigation about User trends support
Description:
Background:
Operating any dynamic process is a difficult cognitive process and operators have to work with thousands numbers, status indications that is spread out over dozens of graphics, thus the need of High Performance HMI. One of the key way to handle such process data is to understand how data is approaching or direction of the data so that it helps the operator to understand the details such as rate of changes, possible future trend line, etc., The trend lines are superimposed on top of a graph w.r.t to amplitude of the data and time. The trend lines are plotted based on various data sources, typically historical and real-time. 

Scope:
Investigation about user trend support shall be carried and necessary changes in the architecture is proposed and agreed with stake holders.

Title: Object Explorer | Containerization

Title: Trend Cont. | Trim View in Trend Chart area
Description:
Background:
Operating any dynamic process is a difficult cognitive process and operators have to work with thousands numbers, status indications that is spread out over dozens of graphics, thus the need of High Performance HMI. One of the key way to handle such process data is to understand how data is approaching or direction of the data so that it helps the operator to understand the details such as rate of changes, possible future trend line, etc., The trend lines are superimposed on top of a graph w.r.t to amplitude of the data and time. The trend lines are plotted based on various data sources, typically historical and real-time. The trend chart is divided into the two portions to visualize both of these data. Real-time based plotting is also known as trim curves which typically shows more samples in comparison with historical data. Typically when a trend group is launched for a time scope, trend curves values are acquired from historical data source and plotted, any consecutive updates from there on is based on real-time acquisition until that particular group is refreshed, the historical values are pushed towards left, and real-time value is plotted as long that particular group is kept opened for that specific time scope.

Scope:
Trend chart shall support trim curves and it shall plot the real-time data acquired using OPC UA DA interface.

Use "Log type" to distinguish trim curve and history curve. If the value of Log type is Trim, then it's trim curve. Otherwise it's history curve.

Use 5000 points for trim curve buffer
  • data on changed should be stored only
  • data storage shall be allocated dynamically

Title: Trend: Auto Scaling Basic
Description:
Automatically scale a curve to its visible min/max range so that the whole screen is occupied. 

Basic functionalities:
- Automatically scale a curve to its visible min/max range, for both single trend and multiple trend. If single signal, then single Y scale shows. If multiple signals, the multiple Y scales show.

- Click on selected tags on the legend and right-click to view context menus and then select "auto-scale" option from the menu. If you don't select any particular curve and click on auto-scale then all visible curves will be auto-scaled by default.

Title: Container | Pod Security management without high level privileges
Description:
Pod Security management without high level privileges

Description
now Pod runing with privilege rights and run as root, all the privileges rights need to be removed, and pod need to run as non-root user.

Major Steps of the Solution

  1. Modify Dockerfile

    • Build image with a dedicated user and group to run container as non-root.
    • Copy files with specific user via COPY [--chown=<user>:<group>] and specific user path.
    • Declare ports above 1024 as non-root user cannot bind to < 1024.

  2. Modify Container Security of Helm Chart template

    • Run containers as specific non-root user.
    • Disable privilege escalation.

  3. Modify Enforce Pod Security Standards with Namespace Labels to baseline

  4. Modify Security Context Constraint (SCC) to nonroot

Title: Team Zena | Bug backlog reduction for SPI 23.4
Description:
Background:
As part of NGT HMI's Quality Management Plan, it is necessary to keep the bug count to low. Any bug shall not have more than 3 months of lead time as per # M25 "Bug Answering Performance" stated in section 5.2 Key Performance Indicators. Hence it is necessary to keep the bug lead time within target lead time by addressing them in timely manner.

Scope:

In general, bugs linked to this WI on or before PI planning 23.4 shall be considered as scope bugs and shall be addressed within PI23.4. Title: Audit Event communication failure handling
Description: In case of any communication failure, audit events must be buffered and transferred once the connection is reestablished. Buffering must happen on disk and not just in memory in case of a power failure or shutdown. Buffering time should be considered that it can be weeks or even months, even though it is typically a much smaller time frame.

Basic Alarm & Event List: NLS
Alarm list | Alarm Shelving
Description:
Alarm shelving allows the operators to temporarily remove standing or nuisance alarms from the main alarm list and places it on the shelve list.
The required configuration for shelving is from config file for now.
Shelving Enabled,  (True/False)
Shelving Time - selectable list of shelving times. (1 Hour, 2 Hours, 4 Hours, 8 Hours)
Shelving Reasons - selectable list of reasons. ("Signal Noise", "Instrumentation malfunction", "Lack of Maintenance".
"Reason for Shelving" and "Comment" fields are disabled for now as 800xA OPC UA Server do not support it. Possible when 800xA OPC UA Server implements 1.5.x Spec.


Alarm list should have tool bar button for shelving. Which will be enabled if below points are true
- Shelving functionality is enabled.
- license for Shelving is available for system ( descoped for PI 23.4, Should be considered in next PI.) 
- Alarm is selected in an Alarm list view.

Button should give shelve/unshelve option based on Alarm state (not shelved/shelved) of selected alarm.

Below are the parameters need to provide while shelving an alarm. A popup window is required which can allow operator to enter these parameters.

Shelving configuration defines how operators can shelve the alarms. There are two ways
to shelve the alarms:
– Standard Shelving.
Standard shelving allows the operators to shelve the alarms temporarily for a
specified time. Recurrences of the alarm because of a state change will not appear
in the main list until the specified time has elapsed.
– One-shot Shelving.
One-shot shelving will place the alarm in the shelf only once. When the state of the
alarm changes, the alarm is automatically removed from the shelf. Further instances
of the alarm will appear in the main list.

– Shelving Time.
Shelving time indicates the maximum time allowed for an alarm before the alarm is
removed from the shelf. System administrators can add or remove shelving times
from the list according to the plant specifications.

- Shelving Reasons. (This filed should be disabled for now, as it is not supported by 800xA OPC UA Server) 
Operators can select a shelving reason from the list of reasons provided.

- Comments . (This filed should be disabled for now, as it is not supported by 800xA OPC UA Server) 

Alarm list should have tool bar button for shelving alarm list, which can be used to view shelved alarms.

Title: Basic Trend | Highlighting signal post cross navigation
Description:
Background: Menu and toolbar play vital role in Operator Workplace and user experience. Typically, this is the first thing that the operator looks for in an Operator workplace and well-designed and contextual menu which is simplified in nature makes navigation quicker and faster. Hence, It is important to make any menu system quicker and faster, one the way to avoid multiple clicks to go to desired navigation, the flyout are typically a page menu that visually generates hierarchy menu (incl. parent and child) that fly's out when user hover over it or clicking using standard interactions methods such as mouse hoover or right click. Alternatively, the flyout also known as Tree-menu where the invoking method from user might be different.

Scope: In case of trend group is launched using standard context menu option, the respective parent tag through which trend group is being launched shall be highlighted.

Title: Workplace | Navigation parameters to support PG2 navigation request
Description:
Background: Navigation request send from PG2 to Workplace using an INavigationRequest with the data field set to a dictionary of strings.

Given a navigation request where the given id is a graphic display:
{"id":"{56d187c4-86d1-4411-b18b-b476f9473a46}:{71d833f9-48c7-498e-b3c1-7d7f3e42e17b}","mode":null,"screen":null,"target":"Base2","data":{"val1":"First value","val2":"Second value"}}

Scope:

A navigation shall be performed on the dedicated pane and the returning data should contain a structure containing a data structure similar to following:

"id": "{56d187c4-86d1-4411-b18b-b476f9473a46}:{71d833f9-48c7-498e-b3c1-7d7f3e42e17b}",
        "data": {
          "val1": "First value",
          "val2": "Second value"
        }
      }

Title: Workplace | UX | Multi-Window Handling Definition-Part2
Description:
Background:
Typically workplace provides number of configurable options that allows the user to customize the workplace. Currently these configuration are provided by a static configuration file (JSON) file. Workplace allows the user to access the required graphics, alarm list, event list, and trend group of a specific area in a specific monitor and there shall be multiple monitors where each monitors having its own workplace with its own configuration. Typically each monitors provides workplaces with specific layouts where multiple client windows such as graphics, trends, alarm list, and event list are organized in horizontal, vertical or in a quad manner as per the process needs that is defined by workplace layout. Using workplace layout also means that applications can be moved from one monitor to another, or be displayed simultaneously on more than one monitor. Workplace layout are typically specific to the user.

Scope:
 UI/UX for workplace layout shall be defined. The following items shall be considered while designing the workplace,
  1. The workplace shall be high performance by design
  2. Secure by design
  3. Fail-safe and fault tolerant
  4. Scalable and reliable
  5. Easy and hassle free navigation
The basic workplace layout shall have vital components such as hamburger menu, user info, date & time indicators, alarm band, alarm sequence band, flyout menu, tree navigation, layout management such as arranging the windows horizontally, vertically, and quad manner, windows can be moved across monitors, safe area definition, each window shall have title displays name of the content being visualized, toolbar, layout preserving mechanism, hang indicators of windows, full screen mode to arranged view switching & vice versa, recent window history for easy switching, each window management (minimize, maximize, restore, and close), auto arrange management of windows, zoom in and zoom out windows,

Title: WebPG2 Performance - Blazor Multiview Rendering POC
Description:
Creating multiple Blazor applications within iFrames will eat up a lot of memory.
We have the need to show at least 10 components rendered by graphics.

Today, each opened "window" will create a new Blazor application, loading all assemblies and dotnet into
this application where the graphics is shown. The application is hosted within an iFrame.
Opening and creating instances of the application is managed by the "WindowsManager" (workplace) where
it creates a DIV containing an iFrame and navigating to the graphics (Blazor microservice) URL.

What we want is somehow to be able to render to multiple DIVs within this "WindowsManager" dynamically
(or restricted to a specific number of DIVs). We need to have ONE Blazor application loaded that can render
to these DIVs hosted by the "WindowsManager".
How do we render Blazor components outside of the Blazor applicaion, e.i. on any div within the "Workplace".

Notes:
Headless Blazor [Done]

Collaboration between Sierra, Zena and Microsoft.

A widget shall be created that can be opened in the workplace that is being updated by a headless Blazor service running in the background.

Onboarding CommonHMI for our team.

A widget that can be instantiated by the workplace is available. A workplace configuration with buttons to create instances of the widget. A headless Blazor application is hosted by the shell as a workplace service. The widget communicates with the service to register render targets.

How to access static files from the Blazor application?
Investigate PG2 caps to render to multiple views, i.e. remove static dependencies (possible work for MS guys)

After workshop

POC leftovers:

  • Recap with Davide regarding static resources fonts, js etc. Outcome handled or documented
    • Dynamic static resources like fonts + font CSS will be served by Graphics Backend. Resources will have to be prepended by /pg2/ route.
    • Need to preload CSS someway
    • Feature for resources and pipeline artifacts + TS conversion
    • Make Widget and service to work in WM POC again. Get rid of the tinyHMI related hack for JS interops and find a common way.
  • Dual widget in WM again but only one with . Why did it not work when Michael made it work?
  • What dev runtime modes to implement and how.
    • Use dynamic roots with shadow DOM
    • TinyHMI. Possible to debug?
    • Run "normal" working Blazor (without shadow root) as today to be able to investigate difference.
  • Blazor event binding in shadow DOM not working. (display selector, Controls ViewList etc). Investigate workaround. Figure out workaround and identify all usage of not working bindings.
    • Workarounds for DEW investigated
    • Control host instances and binding
    • Feature for bindings and separation in to instances
    • Dew Popup: Non working keyboard events and placement of dew. Is it also the shadow root binding problem or just mistake in refactoring during workshop? Enter, Esc not working, Scroll not working when mouse over dew. .
    • Positioning of popups and DEWs. Works in TinyHMI but not in real shadow DOM. May relate to component size. Size must relate to SD DIV not window size.
      • Window size events on the correct element instead of window include styling to get the widget element, if that is the one, to resize to parent element size. Use ResizeObserver?
  • JavaScript instance to graphics display instance mapping and communication in both  directions.
  • In current POC texts inside SVG are selectable in browser. Can this be disabled just for graphics?
    • Separate CSS for graphics? 
    • Scope CSS with namespace.
  • Disable default context menu. Not working in branch investigate.

  

Next Increment part of new feature(s):

  • How to handle the mapping between root instance connection to graphics c#? One adapter one widget instance. Refactor POC?
    • Visual connection to correct SVG model instance.
    • Injection of HTML events to correct SVG model.
  • using di services etc.
  • Pipeline to build artifacts for new CHMI
    • Frontend Widget/Service one or two artifacts?
    • Backend
  • Maybe restructure the solution based on artifacts?
  • Refactor POC implementations to production code
  • Make graphics work with dual displays. What statics and singletons to keep and what to make as transient, per display. This was our initial planned feature
  • Workplace interaction
    • Navigation request
    • Context menu invocation
    • Status updates from graphics to workplace (load state)
    • DI usage instead of NGT-window object.
      • Port JS to TS. Build modules and import/export so we can code with type and directly
  • Navigation parameters input
    • How do we get the navigation parameters
  • Prevent memory leakage
    • Event handler deletion

Object Explorer can be accessed from the burger menu. Select the plant structure to view respective objects/tags and select one of the objects/tags to view its properties. UX design: Operations Client Step 2 - Overview (azure.com).

Title: SR-5910 Adapt Object Directory to NGT Operations information model
Description:
As of today the object directory contains data in the same format as stored in 800xA, i.e. aspects, objects, 800xA structure information. Furthermore identification of different views (i.e. Trend, Alarm List) is hardcoded to AspectTypeIds from 800xA and the solution is not dynamic to automatic update things like context menu or listing of "aspects" seamless.

NGT generally has a new information model, unfortunately it is not 100% clear and defined. Some concepts are there and some are missing. However, we as Operations can still define (and have in the architecture group done/started doing so) which is inspired by the concepts of NGT information model. This is based or OPC UA rather than OPC Classic and it allows us to model things a bit differently than how it is done in 800xA. This in combination with the "deploy" step allows us to pre-calculate some things that otherwise would need to be calculated in runtime.

The information model is described in the operations wiki:
ObjectDirectory - Overview (azure.com)

Database
Create a database scheme for storing the ObjectDirectory information in a way so that it can be queried efficiently.

Note: To be able to work with runtime-implementation it is probably a good idea to "by-hand"- populate the data instead of waiting for engineering parts to be done.

Runtime

Create a new (or update the current) ObjectDirectory access nuget which allows access of the information easily from different HMI BE Services. 
When this is done, we step by step need to migrate our applications to start using the new information model.

Engineering/configuration

All the new information as described in the information model needs to be available in the ObjectDirectory database. Today it is populated via the deploy tool but we dont really know how it will be done in the next step.
Either we need to update the deploy tool or start introducing a model service and NGT engineering.

Title: Workplace | UX | Multi-Screen Handling Definition
Description:
Background:
Typically workplace provides number of configurable options that allows the user to customize the workplace. Currently these configuration are provided by a static configuration file (JSON) file. Workplace allows the user to access the required graphics, alarm list, event list, and trend group of a specific area in a specific monitor and there shall be multiple monitors where each monitors having its own workplace with its own configuration. Typically each monitors provides workplaces with specific layouts where multiple client windows such as graphics, trends, alarm list, and event list are organized in horizontal, vertical or in a quad manner as per the process needs that is defined by workplace layout. Using workplace layout also means that applications can be moved from one monitor to another, or be displayed simultaneously on more than one monitor. Workplace layout are typically specific to the user.

In general, the workplace may have a single or a multi-screen setup. In the multi-screen, setup, one screen can, for instance be dedicated to always show alarms and another to always present the trend.

Scope:
 UI/UX for workplace layout shall be defined. The following items shall be considered while designing the workplace,
  1. The workplace shall be high performance by design
  2. Secure by design
  3. Fail-safe and fault tolerant
  4. Scalable and reliable
  5. Easy and hassle free navigation
The multi-screen management compliments the feature #169551 & #179934 and shall be designed while keep the workplace layout features in consideration. The Multi-screen management means that a workplace with specific layout can visualized in a specific screen. Typically multi-screen shall be upto 4 nos. There shall be seamless windows movements between one screen to another. The windows shall be by default opened in a screen where they're launched, however it shall be also possible to define the designated screen and position when required, of course such windows handling or movements shall be subject to safe area definition. The no. of screens shall be defined as part of workplace configuration.

For any reason, if the user moved one workplace of a specific screen to another screen where now multiple workplaces being visualized in a screen, the recent one shall be forced closed after elasping some timer or showing some warning message.

Note: It is expected that all screens have same resolution.

Title: SR-5873 Workplace |  Mutli-view support
Description:
Background:
Typically workplace provides number of configurable options that allows the user to customize the workplace. Currently these configuration are provided by a static configuration file (JSON) file. Workplace allows the user to access the required graphics, alarm list, event list, and trend group of a specific area in a specific monitor and there shall be multiple monitors where each monitors having its own workplace with its own configuration. Typically each monitors provides workplaces with specific layouts where multiple client windows such as graphics, trends, alarm list, and event list are organized in horizontal, vertical or in a quad manner as per the process needs that is defined by workplace layout. Using workplace layout also means that applications can be moved from one monitor to another, or be displayed simultaneously on more than one monitor. Workplace layout are typically specific to the user.

Scope:
Workplace shall support opening of multiple view of any HMI application such as PG2 graphics, trends, object explorer, alarm list and event list. It shall support content visualization techniques like preserve and replace. The definition of multiple shall be up to 4 number for any unique HMI application (aspect types).

Title: Workplace | Tree Navigation | End-User Documentation
Description:
Background: Menu and toolbar play vital role in Operator Workplace and user experience. Typically this is the first thing that the operator looks for in a Operator workplace and well-designed and contextual menu which is simplified in nature makes navigation quicker and faster. Hence, It is important to make any menu system quicker and faster, one the way to avoid multiple clicks to go to desired navigation, the flyout are typically a page menu that visually generates hierarchy menu (incl. parent and child) that flys out when user hover over it or clicking using standard interactions methods such as mouse hoover or right click. Alternatively, the flyout also known as Tree-menu where the invoking method from user might be different.

Scope: The Tree navigation features and functionalities shall be described in End-User documentation of Web Client Workplace.

Title: Updating Trust List & CRL from GDS Certificate Manager to OPC UA Servers
Description: certificate management user interface List all applications that have been registered. The system administrator can select single or multiple UA applications from the list. Import a single or multiple PKI certificates and their CRLs that need to be added to the trust list of the selected application. Using the rest API, a selected certificate can be sent to the system management back end. Certificate Management's web back end can send the same to GDS Certificate Manager using the OPC UA method, and GDS Certificate Manager will add it to its trust list. Trust list updates are for any UA server, and GDS Certificate Manager will notify Push Manager, who will then push those trust lists to the device or PC's UA server. Periodically, LCS will check with GDS Certificate Manager on changes to the trust list for any UA client applications in the node. If LCS finds any new changes, it will get them from GDS Certificate Manager and update the trust list of the corresponding application in that node.

Title: SR-5876 Web Trend Continuation - 800xA 7.0
Description:
Background: Operator Trends are dynamic graphic displays that shows the progress of tag values with reference to time. The display presents the process values as a continuous line on an x, y graph/chart. The x-axis is referenced to time while y-axis is the value of the signal. Trending tag or object values are helpful to monitor process changes during the plant operations. NGT HMI project developed Trend component in a incremental manner starting from Release 2.0 and it is expected to evolve with feature and functionalities in future releases such as Release 2.0 RU1, and Release 3.0

Narration: In General, trend feature left over from 2.0 shall be considered into this WI. It includes features of Knowledge Extractor contributed items as well. The following items are shall be considered as scope of work under this WI.

Current Value in Trend Legend: The legend area of the trend shall have a dedicated column header (user configurable toggling field) that displays the real-time value acquired using OPC UA DA interface of respective signal/object.

Basic Auto Scaling: It shall be possible to apply auto scaling to signals available in trend group using a toolbar button. When applied so, min and max values of visible range + buffer shall be applied, and Y-Scale is visualized accordingly.

Logical Color Support: Trend component shall support logical colors where it is applicable such as chart area, background, signal/object specific colors, these colors configurations shall be inherited from System 800xA Configurations (Trend Colors of Workplace and Trend configurations of Trend aspect).

Title: NGT ThinClient | Web browser compatibility in Mobile Devices
Description:
Background: Web applications brings lot of advantages in terms of multiple users using same version of the application, zero installation, accessing in various platforms ranging from desktop to mobile devices, multiple browser compatibility and so on. Considering above Operations Client is expected to support multiple platforms and browsers such as mobile device and different browsers such as Chromium based browser and Safari.

Scope: The Operations Client functionalities shall be tested against the following browser running in different platforms. 
  1. Safari running in iPad OS.
  2. Chrome running in Android.
The test shall be focused on browser compatibility (version), functionalities, layout changes, touch support, gesture supports, error handling, theme changes due to the platform, performance, and hardware footprint usages.

Manual test shall be executed to give initial feedback and it is also necessary to identify suitable TA solution with proposed architecture. If possible, POC of TA is preferred.

The test focus shall be on Team Zena's components such as Workplace and Trends. However, the experience and lessons learned to be shared across NGT HMI project.

Title: Workplace | Tree Navigation Support (without overlay support)
Description:
Background: Menu and toolbar play vital role in Operator Workplace and user experience. Typically this is the first thing that the operator looks for in a Operator workplace and well-designed and contextual menu which is simplified in nature makes navigation quicker and faster. Hence, It is important to make any menu system quicker and faster, one the way to avoid multiple clicks to go to desired navigation, the flyout are typically a page menu that visually generates hierarchy menu (incl. parent and child) that flys out when user hover over it or clicking using standard interactions methods such as mouse hoover or right click. Alternatively, the flyout also known as Tree-menu where the invoking method from user might be different.

Scope: 

Tree menu will be populated based on database that is based on System 800xA's Functional Structure, generated and deployed using standard engineering workflow(This means any changes post deployment would mean re-deploy). 

To optimize the navigation efficiency there shall be a efficient way of implementing tree menu such as in the initial loading it only shows the parent thus need of retrieving respective childs until unless parent is clicked and displaying them shall be avoided, in other words lazy loading. It shall be possible to navigate to PG2, Trends, and alarm list aspect types.

The UI/UX shall be based on proposed UI/UX, any restructuring of UI element in current implementation shall be done accordingly. 
Out of Scope: Tree navigation and doesn't support multiple browser windows and overlay navigation.

Predecessor: System 800xA Deploy Tool to be ready and tree navigation info is included in the workplace DB. Unable to link the WI from OCS collection, hence mentioning here as text.

Title: SR-5879 Containerization - Step 1
Description:
Become familiar with Linux and Docker, Containerize services with help from DE CRC. Attend a workshop. Based on the workshop's outcomes add Docker image build into the service's build pipeline and publish the container to PCP's Docker registry. A default/sample configuration of the container should be provided that can be loaded to the container via a volume. It is documented how to run the container and all of its dependencies are described. A Docker Compose file that can launch all services required by the Panel is available and kept up-to-date.

.NET-based services should use the Microsoft base OS images (mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspnet:6.0). C++ or other containers should ideally based on Alpine Linux, however this is not a must.

Some additional information:
The Digital-ABB-PCP-Registry library contains address, with username and password (ABBPCPDevRegistry, ABBPCPDevRegistryAdminUserName and ABBPCPDevRegistryAdminPassword).
 
There’s also a service connection available.

K3s is foreseen to be used as an Orchestrator (t.b.c.). Extra hardening of containers is not foreseen in this Epic. This will be handled separately. It should however be avoided that containers require privileged mode to run. 

Demo: A set of containers required for Panel is running on a single node and initially orchestrated using K3S (or Docker compose).

In the first step we will treat the LCS as a separate container. However, we shall bear in mind that the final architecture assumes that the LCS will be running as a process within each container requiring certificates.
